As early as the 1930s, there were plans to build a high-speed freeway to Los Angeles, but the project was abandoned due to financial problems.[1] In the years following World War II, California became the epicenter of the automobile industry, and highways were a priority for the state. Highway construction boomed in the 1950s and 1960s, resulting in the construction of nearly a dozen interstates, which served as conduits for millions of cars and trucks each year. This was in contrast to the pre-war era, when the state did not build any highways at all for more than a decade. A total of more than 3,000 miles (5,000 km) of freeway were built between 1950 and the mid-1970s, most of which were freeway extensions of existing freeways. These were known as "expressways" for their express purpose of bypassing traffic-clogged urban areas.

Hattiesburg is a city in the state of Mississippi.[1] It is the capital of the Delta region of the state, and one of the largest cities in the United States by population. Its population is 2,622,892 as of 2077, making it the 14th largest city in the United States after New York City, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Chicago, and Washington, D.C. (Note that this is a lower bound, as the city has grown over the years due to growth in the state as a whole, and not just in the city itself.)

" Ball erected a station house on the Mobile and Ohio Railroad – the sign on which would alternate between " Meridian " and " Sowashee " each day. The town was officially incorporated as Meridian on February 10, 1860.

On the other side of the Atlantic, an American newspaper was opposed to the name, as it was "too grandiose in its connotation." The British newspaper The Spectator went so far as to suggest renaming the settlement "Meridian, U.S.A." (sic). This was followed by a series of editorials in the British and American press arguing that the name had no place in the world at the time. One of the most eloquent was written by Lord Palmerston, the British Prime Minister, who in 1848 referred to the settlement as "Middletown, the home of free and enlightened men."


By the time the decision was made, the townspeople had grown tired of the argument and settled on the name that stuck for the rest of the century. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Meridian was a small village at the start of the American Civil War in 1861. Its strategic position at the railroad junction led to the Confederate construction of several military
reference_text: installations to support the war. During the Battle of Meridian in 1864, General William Tecumseh Sherman led troops into the city, destroying the railroads in every direction, as well as an arsenal and immense storehouses ; his forces burned much of the buildings to the ground. Sherman is reported to have said afterwards, " Meridian, with its depots, store @-@ houses, arsenal, hospitals, offices, hotels, and cantonments no longer exists. " Despite the destruction, the railroad lines in the city were rapidly repaired, back in operation 26 working days after the battle. Race relations remained tense during the Reconstruction era, with the riot of 1871 following a fire that damaged many businesses.

Meridian was home to an iron foundry, a sawmill, a smelting plant, and a cotton gin. The townspeople were divided on the war, with some supporting the Confederacy and others siding with the Union. One of the most prominent citizens was John F. Lynch, a well-known abolitionist and anti-slavery crusader. On July 4, 1861, Lynch went to Meridian to deliver a speech to the townspeople. In his speech, Lynch spoke of the injustice of slavery and called for the abolition of slavery in the United States. After the speech, Lynch was arrested and taken to the jail for "inciting sedition." While in jail, Lynch's health began to deteriorate. The jail had no bed, and Lynch slept on the floor for three days and nights. On the fourth day, a group of Union soldiers broke into the jail and lynched Lynch. Lynch's body was left on the jail floor for three days before it was discovered by a passerby. The crowd was infuriated by the lack of justice and rioting broke out in the town. By the end of the day, over one hundred people had been killed and hundreds more injured.

In June 1964, Chaney, Schwerner, and Goodman went to Neshoba County, Mississippi, to meet with members of a black church that had been bombed and burned. Meridian's integration was short-lived, however. On April 2, 1967, President Lyndon Johnson signed the Civil Rights Act of 1964 into law. That same day, Mississippi Governor Ross Barnett declared Meridian a "Negro City," an all-white enclave with little to no access to federal funds and the threat of violence from white supremacists. The decision set off a domino effect of segregation, culminating in the desegregation of Meridian High School two years later.

Mississippi is one of the most segregated states in the country. African Americans make up less than 10 percent of the population, but account for close to a quarter of the prison population. This is a state where the Ku Klux Klan was active in the 1920s and 1930s, and segregationist Jim Crow laws were in place until the Brown v. Board of Education decision in 1954.

It's no surprise that, in the past decade, Republicans have done everything they can to take advantage of this, and they have succeeded. The result was that black Mississippians were denied their right to vote at the polls, and that right was restored in December of that year.

Since then, the state has gone to great lengths to make it harder for people of color to vote. For example, in 2012, the state Supreme Court gutted the Voting Rights Act of 1965, which required states with a history of racial discrimination to get preclearance from the Justice Department before changing their voting laws. A total of 1,715 acres of national forest was transferred to the United States of America in 1872 to provide protection for the Mississippi River and its tributaries. The transfer was made by President Ulysses S. Grant and his Secretary of the Interior, Salmon P. Chase. Grant made the transfer as a condition of the Louisiana Purchase of 1803. At the time, there were no laws in the United States that prohibited the sale of national forests, except for the National Forest Act of 1872. This act, known as the Leflore Act, gave the Secretary of the Interior the authority to sell public lands to private parties for a price that equaled the appraised value of the land. The land was divided into parcels according to acreage and subdivided into allotments of one, two, or three acres. Each parcel was given a title to the land based on the number of acres in the parcel. For example, if the land was an acre and a half, title to the land was given to the owner of the acre and two-thirds of the acre was set aside for the state of Louisiana. After the sale, the land was turned over to the state of Louisiana as long as it remained unsold. As time went on, the state began to take advantage of the land and developed a timber industry that resulted in the state becoming the number one

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The city's former Grand Opera House was built in 1889 by two half brothers, Israel Marks and Levi Rothenberg. During its operation the opera house

A $ 10 million grant in 2000 by the Riley Foundation, a local foundation chartered in 1998, sparked the building's restoration while $ 15 million came from a combination of city, county, and federal grants. The opera house's renovation was completed in September 2006 under the new name " Mississippi State University Riley Center for Education and Performing Arts. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Meridian is rightly considered an architectural treasure trove being one the nations most intact cities from the turn of the last century. Architecture students from around the nation and Canada
reference_text: are known to visit Meridian in groups as part of their coursework due to numerous structures in the city having been designed by noted architects. The only home in the US south designed by noted Canadian born Architect Louis S. Curtiss, famous for inventing the glass curtain wall skyscraper, is extant on Highland Park. The Frank Fort designed Threefoot Building is generally considered one of the best Art Deco skyscrapers in the US and is often compared to Detroit's famed Fisher Building. Noted California Architect Wallace Neff designed a number of homes in Meridian as well as in the Alabama Black Belt which adjoins the city across the nearby Alabama State line. He had relatives in Meridian and Selma who were executives in the then thriving railroad industry and would take commissions in the area when commissions in California were lean. His work is mostly concentrated in the lower numbered blocks of Poplar Springs Drive where his 2516 Poplar Springs Drive is often compared to the similarly designed Falcon Lair, the Beverly Hills home in Benedict Canyon of Rudolph Valentino. One Neff work was lost to an expansion of Anderson Hospital in 1990 and another in Marion Park burned in the 1950s. The Meridian Post Office with its interior done entirely of bronze and Verde marble is also noteworthy as a very fine example of the type of Post Office structures built in thriving and well to do cities in the 1920s and originally had Lalique lighting which was removed sadly during a 1960s remodeling and which are now in private residences on Poplar Springs Drive and in North Hills.

Meridian is a city of 1,845, according to the 2010 census. It is located in the Delta region of Mississippi, about 60 miles (100 km) south of Biloxi, Mississippi. The population of Meridian is estimated at 6,000-8,000.

Morton County, home to Meridian, is one of the poorest counties in the state. Median household income is $22,664, less than half the state average of $51,054. More than a third of the county's residents live below the poverty line. Poverty rates are higher in the city of Meridian than in the county as a whole.

As of 2010, there were no African-American or biracial residents in Meridian. In the mid-1990s, Meridian began to diversify its population, attracting people from other parts of the state and the United States. Many of the newcomers have found work in the construction industry, which has helped revitalize the city.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Early public education in Meridian was based on the 1870 Mississippi Constitution. From 1870 to 1885, trustees appointed by the City Council served on the Board of School
reference_text: Directors, which had authority to operate the schools. Although there were several schools in the city before 1884, they were privately owned and only enrolled about 400 students. The city did not build its first publicly owned school until September 1884. The first public school for blacks in the city was held in facilities rented from St. Paul Methodist Church. The Mississippi Legislature amended the city charter in January 1888 to allow the city to maintain its own municipal school district, and in March of the same year $ 30 @,@ 000 in bonds was approved for the city to build new public schools. From this bond, the Wechsler School was built in 1894, becoming the first brick public school building in the state built for blacks.

On April 1, 1885, the Board of School Commissioners was replaced by the Meridian Board of Education. The school board had the authority to make decisions that affected the district as a whole, but did not have the power to hire and fire teachers. In addition, the board was responsible for providing financial support for the board of education and school buildings. Board members were elected by the school board to serve until their successors were elected. At the time of the reorganization, there were two candidates for each seat on the board. A majority of the board, however, needed to vote in favor of the appointee to be appointed to the position of school superintendent. If the board did not agree, the position was filled by the State Superintendent of Education.

Origin Edit

The word "foula" is a portmanteau of the Portuguese words "fou" (fragile) and "dolhos" (cliff). In Portuguese, the word has come to mean "crab" or "octopus."[1] According to The Simpsons: Tapped Out, there is a town in New South Wales called "Foula" that is named after the word.

Etymology Edit

The word "foula" derives from the Old Portugese word "fou", which means "tumultuous, stormy, tempestuous, turbulent, raucous, tumult, commotion, tumult, commotion, and a number of other adjectives that describe the sound of waves crashing against rocks, sand dunes, sea gulls, etc." This sounds similar to the word "foie gras", which is a delicacy in France and the United Provinces of French Guiana.

Tropical Cyclone Formations

As mentioned in the introduction, it is common to refer to tropical cyclones as "hurricanes" or "typhoons." These terms are used by meteorologists to categorize the types of storms that occur in the tropical Pacific Ocean. However, this does not tell the whole story. For one thing, hurricanes and typhoons are not the same thing. Hurricane intensity is a function of two factors: 1) the intensity of the air that circulates over the storm and 2) the amount of moisture in the atmosphere. When it comes to tropical cyclones, the first factor is more important than the second. This is because, in the tropics, the air is warm and drier than it is in the midlatitudes. The song was written in the early 1930s by John Lee Hooker, a songwriter who went on to write "Whiskey in the Jar" and "You're a Big Girl Now". This was the beginning of his career as a songwriter.

The number of people claiming unemployment benefit in the UK has fallen by more than a million since 2010, official figures show.

Figures from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) show there were 1.5 million claimants in the year to March, a fall of 930,000 on the previous year.

The number of long-term unemployed (LTIs) - those out of work for more than a year - stood at 1.9 million as of March.

Labour said the figures showed the government was "in denial" about the jobless situation.

In order not to interfere with traffic flow during construction, the new interchange was designed largely as elevated flyover ramps and viaducts so they could be built high over the existing junction lanes ; once traffic was transferred to the new structures the old lanes could simply be closed off and removed. Little of the original interchange remained when the project was finished.

That race saw a caution for rain with five laps left before the halfway point. It took the drivers 26 minutes to complete the laps, and the rain was so heavy that some drivers had to look out their side windows because they could not see out their windshields. Two hours later, the track had dried and the race resumed with Richmond in third. After Richmond's car was adjusted to remove the " push ", the car was more to his liking. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The terrain in the Trout Creek Mountains varies from broad, flat basins and rolling ridges to high rock escarpments cut by deep canyons.
reference_text: The canyons have steep walls with loose talus slopes at the bottoms. There are meadows around springs in the mountains, although most streams in the range do not flow year @-@ round. Major streams that flow off the north slopes of the mountains include ( from west to east ) Cottonwood Creek, Trout Creek, Willow Creek, and Whitehorse Creek. These streams all flow into endorheic basins in Harney County, Oregon. Trout Creek and Whitehorse Creek are the largest of the four. The Kings River and McDermitt Creek each drain an area on the south slopes of the Trout Creek Mountains. The Kings River begins in The Granites and flows south into Nevada, where it meets the Quinn River, which evaporates in the Black Rock Desert. McDermitt Creek begins in Oregon a few miles north of The Granites and flows generally east, crossing the Oregon – Nevada border five times before disappearing into the floor of the Quinn River Valley south of McDermitt.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The Trout Creek Mountains are composed mostly of basalt from a shield volcano that once stood where Steens Mountain is today. Crustal thinning and the
reference_text: Yellowstone hotspot, which was then beneath southeastern Oregon, induced eruptions from Steens and nearby vents about 17 million years ago, in the Miocene. The vents produced a series of lava flows that spread across the land now known as the Trout Creek Mountains. Eruptions from the Steens volcano lasted for about one million years, and at least 70 separate lava flows occurred. Under the resulting basalt rock lie much older metamorphic rocks that may be related to some of the Triassic age formations of the Blue Mountains in northeastern Oregon. Within these metamorphic rocks are diorite and granodiorite intrusive bodies which were presumably intruded during the Cretaceous Period.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The broad McDermitt Caldera is a prominent geologic feature in the Trout Creek Mountains. The oval @-@ shaped caldera is a collapsed
reference_text: lava dome that straddles the Oregon – Nevada border on the eastern side of the range and south of the Oregon Canyon Mountains. It is about 28 miles ( 45 km ) long and 22 miles ( 35 km ) wide. The lava dome was created by volcanic eruptions in the early Miocene. A total of five large ash flows were produced along with a large rhyolite dome structure. The caldera formed when the dome collapsed about 16 million years ago. The caldera contains significant ore deposits, and mercury and uranium have been mined at eight or more sites in and around the caldera. Other areas in the caldera were mined for ores of antimony, cesium, and lithium.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The Trout Creek Mountains are semi @-@ arid because they are in the eastern rain shadow of mountain ranges to the west. When moist air from the
reference_text: Pacific Ocean moves eastward over the Oregon and California coastal ranges and the Cascade Range, most precipitation falls in those mountains before reaching the Trout Creek Mountains. As a result, the average annual precipitation in the Trout Creek Mountains is only 8 to 26 inches ( 200 to 660 mm ) per year, with most areas receiving between 8 and 12 inches ( 200 and 300 mm ) annually. Much of the annual precipitation occurs between the beginning of March and the end of June. Most of the rest falls as snow during the fall and winter months. Snowpack at elevations below 6 @,@ 000 feet ( 1 @,@ 800 m ) usually melts by April ; however, at the higher elevations, snow can remain until mid @-@ June. Local flooding often occurs in the spring as the snowpack melts.

Narrow riparian greenways follow the year @-@ round streams. Many greenway areas have quaking aspen and willow groves. Cottonwood and alder groves can be found at lower elevations where terrain is flatter and stream channels are wider. Sedges and rushes are also native to these stream bottoms. Years of heavy livestock grazing in parts of the range resulted in the loss of some grass species, riparian vegetation, and young aspen and willow trees. Restoration of riparian areas began in the early 1970s, and plans to reduce grazing were implemented in the 1980s and early 1990s. Wetlands provide habitat for a wide variety of wildlife, including migratory waterfowl, shorebirds, amphibians, salamanders, reptiles, and invertebrates. In addition, wetlands play a key role in flood control and sediment and nutrient removal. For example, wetlands remove sediments from streams and reduce the amount of silt that accumulates in the river bottoms. This in turn helps to maintain a healthy hydrologic cycle and contributes to the long-term health of the Chesapeake Bay.


Prairie Habitat in the U.S. is under threat from climate change, urbanization, and invasive species. The most common threats to prairie habitat are overgrazing, soil erosion, and fire. These threats are exacerbated by the warming climate, which is leading to drier conditions and increased evaporation of water from the soil. As a result, there is a growing need for research to understand the effects of climate change on prairie habitat. This research is critical to our understanding of how we can help native prairie species adapt to changing conditions and to the management of prairie habitat in the 21st century.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Several streams in the Trout Creek Mountains are home to trout, including the rare Lahontan cutthroat trout subspecies. These include Willow Creek, White
reference_text: horse Creek, Little Whitehorse Creek, Doolittle Creek, Fifteen Mile Creek, Indian Creek, Sage Canyon Creek, Line Canyon Creek, and some tributaries of McDermitt Creek. Lahontan cutthroat trout live in small, isolated populations that are often confined to individual streams, many of them in the Trout Creek Mountains. These populations have significant genetic differences due to their history of isolation. For most of the 20th century, the trout's numbers declined considerably. It was listed under federal law as an endangered species in 1970 and was reclassified as threatened in 1975. Reasons for the fish's decline included habitat degradation from cattle grazing, drought, overfishing, competition with other fish, and hybridization with introduced rainbow trout, which decreased the number of genetically pure Lahontan cutthroat trout. However, reductions in cattle grazing in riparian zones since the 1980s allowed fish habitat and populations to start to recover.

There are several factors that determine the age of a stream, including the amount of snowmelt it receives each year, how much water evaporates from the topsoil and surface water, and the flow of water through the stream. This is one of the reasons it is difficult to say with certainty how old a stream is.

Streams that have been dammed for hydroelectric power, however, are a good indicator of their age. In this case, the age of the dam is an indication of the age of the stream. For example, an 18-foot-high dam built in the 1930s and maintained by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) would be at least 100 years old.

Other sources of information are historical maps and topographic maps that show the contour lines of the forested and riparian areas in the watershed. Mines in what was called the Opalite Mining District produced 270 @,@ 000 flasks of mercury — " the richest supply of mercury in the western hemisphere " — from cinnabar extracted from the caldera in the 20th century. The McDermitt Mine, the last mercury mine in the United States, closed three years later, in 1992. However, mineral exploration has continued at the Cordero Mine in the 21st century, and waste containing mercury and arsenic was returned there from the community of McDermitt as part of a U.S. Environmental Protection Agency cleanup project.

Mycena maculata, an arboreal nematode, thrives in decomposing wood and has been known to infest a wide range of tree species, including maples, oaks, birch, poplars and elms.

The fungal pathogen is most commonly found in deciduous and coniferous trees, but in recent years has been found in evergreens as well.

According to a study published in the journal Phytopathology, M. maculata's life cycle is influenced by temperature, moisture and soil conditions.

Researchers at the University of Iowa found that temperatures above 32 degrees Fahrenheit are necessary for the fungus to germinate, a process that takes two to three years.

At that point, the fungus reproduces by sporulating, or releasing spores, which are inhaled by tree roots and penetrate the tree's vascular tissue.

Radcliffe was the youngest of three children born to film producer David Heyman and actress Joanna Lumley. His parents divorced when he was six, and he spent his childhood in Los Angeles, New York and London.

After graduating from Eton with a first class degree in English literature, he went on to study drama at Harrow, where he played Hamlet in Peter Brook's production of Julius Caesar. The following year, he won a scholarship to St Martin's School of Dramatic Art in London, where he studied under Ken Loach and Anthony Minghella.

From the age of 16, Radcliffe worked as a trainee scriptwriter for BBC drama series Coronation Street and EastEnders, before taking a series of part-time roles in stage productions, including Richard III at the Donmar Warehouse in London, as well as Shakespeare's Macbeth at the Barbican in London.

In the mid-1990s, he began to make his directorial debut with the low-budget thriller Under the Pyrenees, which was nominated for an Academy Award for best foreign language film. This led to his first feature film, Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, in which he played the eponymous character.

History

Origins

Routes 29 and 30 were part of the Interstate Highway System (IHS) that was created in the 1950s to connect the East Coast and West Coast of the United States. The IHS was the first intermodal highway system in the world, and one of the first to use airfreight as a means of transporting goods. As a result, there were a number of accidents that took place on the Interstate Highway System, including the death of President John F. Kennedy in 1963 due to a head-on collision between a TWA 707 and a Cessna Caravan en route to Los Angeles.[1]

Construction

On June 1, 1956, an agreement was signed between the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) and the New Jersey Department of Transportation (NJDOT) to construct a four-lane highway in the Garden State. The state-owned land was divided into sections, and work began on each section in a staggered fashion over the next two years. By the end of the construction period, NJDOT had completed construction of the first section of Route 29, which was known as the State Route 29 (SR-29)

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Route 29 was initially designated in 1927 to run from downtown Trenton to Newark, following present @-@ day Route 179 and US 202 between Lambertville and
reference_text: Somerville and US 22 between Somerville and Newark. The route between Lambertville and Frenchtown was originally Route 29A. In 1953, Route 29 was shifted to follow the alignment of Route 29A to avoid the concurrencies with the U.S. Routes. Route 29 between South Warren Street in Trenton and I @-@ 95 in Ewing Township was upgraded to a four @-@ lane highway, with a portion of freeway, in the 1950s and 1960s. In 1995, the southern freeway part of Route 29 between I @-@ 195 / I @-@ 295 and Route 129 in Hamilton Township was completed. This freeway section was linked to the rest of Route 29 by a tunnel completed in 2002. A realignment of Route 29 in Lambertville by the 2000s made the route concurrent with the entire length of 0 @.@ 26 @-@ mile @-@ long ( 0 @.@ 42 km ) Route 165.

Routes [ edit ]

There are two ways to travel Route 29: north and south. This article concentrates on the north-south route.

Map of Route 29 (courtesy of Google Maps)

In the mid-1990s, the New Jersey Turnpike Authority (NJTPA) began to reroute I-295 to the north, in order to reduce congestion on the turnpike. This resulted in the creation of a new road, known as Route 29, which was designed to run parallel to I-295 for the first 20 miles or so of its length. After that, the two roads diverged, and became separate thoroughfares.

By the time construction began on the $1.5 billion Hudson-Bergen Light Rail Transit (LRT) line in 2009, it was too late to make the change, and the route remained as it was before: a one-way north-south arterial. As of June 2018, the project is under construction, and scheduled to open in 2023.

In 1892, the City of Lewes, New Jersey was granted a right-of-way to construct a toll road that would connect the city to Atlantic City. Construction began in 1894 and was completed in 1894. The project cost $1,988,000 in today's dollars. At that time, the cost of a round trip was $1.50. This was one of the first toll roads in the United States.


On May 1, 1896, the bridge was opened to traffic. As an added benefit, motorists were able to pay tolls by depositing cash in a bank or credit union and the money was held in escrow until the toll was paid. By the end of the 19th century, Burma had become a province of the British Empire. British rule was in its death throes, and the newly independent country was trying to modernize its military and establish a modern nation-state. In 1882, an expeditionary force led by Brigadier-General Sir Arthur Wellesley landed on the shores of what is now Burma and set up a base of operations. After two years of fighting, the British won the Battle of Sittwe, which resulted in the death of a British general and the capture of the capital Yangon.

On May 1, 1894, the British launched a second invasion of Burma, this time by more than 5,000 troops. The Burma Revolt, as it came to be known, lasted more than a year and ended with the British surrendering to the National League of Burma (NLA), a pro-British coalition of political parties. The NLA was formed in the mid-1890s as a counterweight to the more radical, left-populist party, the Mahomedan Party (MP). The MP held sway over the state for the next 40 years, until independence in 1948.

Mongol invasion of China [ edit ]

[ citation needed ] It is unclear how many people were killed in the invasion, but estimates range from tens of thousands to a million. The most famous victim was the Emperor Taizong, who was taken prisoner and beheaded along with his court. After the death of the emperors, the Chinese had no choice but to capitulate, and the Treaty of Nanking was signed in 1297. It stipulated that the Mongols would be allowed to stay in China for one year, during which time they would build a wall around the city and fortify it. However, the wall was never completed, and the Mongols returned to their homelands in 1298.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Perhaps the most enduring legacy of the Mongol invasions was the emergence of Tai @-@ Shan states in mainland Southeast Asia. The Tai @-@ Shan

By the early 14th century, several Tai @-@ Shan states had come to dominate a vast region from present @-@ day Assam to northern and eastern Myanmar to northern and central Thailand and Laos. Their rise was encouraged by the Mongols, who viewed the states as a useful buffer between Yunnan and the rest of Southeast Asia. The Mongols, who were still trying to incorporate Yunnan into the central administration, were unwilling or unable to make necessary sustained investments to bring the vast regions south of Yunnan into the fold. My interest in the history of South Africa came to a head in the run-up to the 1994 elections, when I was asked to write a history of the Afrikaner Volkspartei (AV) and its leader, PW Botha. At the time, there was no mention of Apartheid in the book, but by the time I got to the writing of it, the ANC had changed its name to the African National Congress (ANC), and was in the process of dissolving the A.V. in order to focus on the party's electoral campaign. As a result, much of the book was reworked, and in the final version, I had to make a number of changes to account for the ANC's change of heart. One of the most significant was the decision to include the liberation struggle as a sub-thematic element in the book. This was an important decision, and one that had to be made with the knowledge that the political situation in South Africa was changing at a rapid pace.

In this post, I want to take a look at the historiography of the liberation struggle in South Africa, and what it tells us about the state of the country today. This is a long post, so bear with me.

History Edit

Tikal was founded by the Toltecs, who came from the south-eastern part of the Isthmus of Tehuantepec to colonize the land that would become the Aztec Empire. According to legend, the Toltecs were able to establish a city by digging a canal through the sand dunes, which allowed them to travel by boat to the island of Tenochtitlan, which was at the time uninhabited. This is a reference to the canal-boring technique known as tunnelling, which was used by the Incas as well. In 1521, the Spaniards arrived in the New World, and began excavating the city with the intention of finding gold. After two years of digging, they found nothing of value, and returned to their ships. A year later, on May 1, 1521, Cortés set foot on the island for the first time. His arrival was heralded by a cacophony of trumpets, which lasted for a full day. The cacophony was so loud that it deafened the ears of anyone who heard it, and many people lost their hearing that day. As a

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Tikal was the capital of a conquest state that became one of the most powerful kingdoms of the ancient Maya. Though monumental architecture at the site dates back as
reference_text: far as the 4th century BC, Tikal reached its apogee during the Classic Period, c. 200 to 900 AD. During this time, the city dominated much of the Maya region politically, economically, and militarily, while interacting with areas throughout Mesoamerica such as the great metropolis of Teotihuacan in the distant Valley of Mexico. There is evidence that Tikal was conquered by Teotihuacan in the 4th century AD. Following the end of the Late Classic Period, no new major monuments were built at Tikal and there is evidence that elite palaces were burned. These events were coupled with a gradual population decline, culminating with the site ’ s abandonment by the end of the 10th century.

Archaeologists from the University of California, Merced, used 3-D models of the city to create a topographical map of the city, which they published in the May/June issue of the peer-reviewed journal PLOS ONE. Tikal was an important city for the Maya, who lived in the Yucatan Peninsula from A.D. 900 to 1521. In the middle of the 10th century, the city was conquered by the Toltecs, who took over the city and built a capital in the city's center. After the conquistadors left, the city continued to grow, and by the 15th century, it had become the largest city in the Yucatan Peninsula. At its peak, Tikal had a population of more than 1,000 people—roughly the same as Los Angeles today.

Early History

The origins of the Aztecs are shrouded in mystery. Historians agree that they came from the north, but it is unclear how they got there. One theory is that they were a nomadic people who settled in the Andes before moving south. Another, more fanciful theory posits that the Aztecs originated in Mesoamerica and crossed the Bering Strait by boat. Whatever the case, the Spaniards were quick to take advantage of the newly discovered land, colonizing the area as soon as they set foot on it.

reference_text: Tikal hiatus " refers to a period between the late 6th to late 7th century where there was a lapse in the writing of inscriptions and large @-@ scale construction at Tikal. In the latter half of the 6th century AD, a serious crisis befell the city, with no new stelae being erected and with widespread deliberate mutilation of public sculpture. This hiatus in activity at Tikal was long unexplained until later epigraphic decipherments identified that the period was prompted by Tikal's comprehensive defeat at the hands of Calakmul and the Caracol polity in AD 562, a defeat that seems to have resulted in the capture and sacrifice of the king of Tikal. The badly eroded Altar 21 at Caracol described how Tikal suffered this disastrous defeat in a major war in April 562. It seems that Caracol was an ally of Calakmul in the wider conflict between that city and Tikal, with the defeat of Tikal having a lasting impact upon the city. Tikal was not sacked but its power and influence were broken. After its great victory, Caracol grew rapidly and some of Tikal's population may have been forcibly relocated there. During the hiatus period, at least one ruler of Tikal took refuge with Janaab'Pakal of Palenque, another of Calakmul's victims. Calakmul itself thrived during Tikal's long hiatus period.

Tikal's fortunes changed when the Mongols invaded in 1260. After a year of siege, the garrison capitulated and fled to the safety of Mount Ararat. They were massacred by the conquerors, and the city was razed to the ground.

Over the next two centuries, the Mongol conquests were the turning point in the history of the Middle East. From that point on, the region was divided into two warring blocs: the Seljuks (Mongol Empire) and the Abbasids (Ottoman Empire). Each of these dynasties had its own capital, and for the most part, this is where you go to learn about the history of the region.

Here are some of the most interesting places to visit in the Middle East and North Africa for history buffs.

Cairo, Egypt

The oldest continuously inhabited city in the world, Cairo is home to the pyramids of Giza and Luxor, as well as the Sphinx. Inhabited since at least 3,000 BC, the city has played a pivotal role in the history of the Middle East, and for good reason.

Located on the Nile River, which flows through the city, the Old City of Cairo dates back to the 18th century

reference_text: Increasingly endemic warfare in the Maya region caused Tikal's supporting population to heavily concentrate close to the city itself, accelerating the use of intensive agriculture and corresponding environmental decline. In 849, Jewel K 'awiil is mentioned on a stela at Seibal as visiting that city as the Divine Lord of Tikal but he is not recorded elsewhere and Tikal's once great power was little more than a memory. A series of catastrophes—droughts, famines, plagues—caused the death of at least 10 million people and the dispersal of an estimated half of the Maya population.

Now, researchers have pinpointed the source of the calamity: a supervolcano known as Popocatepetl-Zalambay, which spewed ash and pumice-like rock from its caldera to the city of Tikal in the Yucatán Peninsula. The research, published in the May/June issue of the journal Quaternary Science Reviews, provides the first evidence that volcanoes are capable of unleashing tsunamis, one of the most devastating forms of natural disaster.

Tikal was the capital of the Mayan civilization, which spanned more than 1,000 years from A.D. 900 to 900 A.D. But by the 10th century, the Classic Maya civilization was in shambles. In one fell swoop, they lost their way of life, leaving behind nothing but ruins. Some scholars have speculated that the collapse was caused by climate change, but there is no consensus on that point. Other research points to human overpopulation as the cause, but this theory has been met with skepticism.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> In the latter half of the 9th century there was an attempt to revive royal power at the much diminished city of Tikal, as evidenced by a st
reference_text: ela erected in the Great Plaza by Jasaw Chan K 'awiil II in 869. This was the last monument erected at Tikal before the city finally fell into silence. The former satellites of Tikal, such as Jimbal and Uaxactun, did not last much longer, erecting their final monuments in 889. By the end of the 9th century the vast majority of Tikal's population had deserted the city, its royal palaces were occupied by squatters and simple thatched dwellings were being erected in the city's ceremonial plazas. The squatters blocked some doorways in the rooms they reoccupied in the monumental structures of the site and left rubbish that included a mixture of domestic refuse and non @-@ utilitarian items such as musical instruments. These inhabitants reused the earlier monuments for their own ritual activities far removed from those of the royal dynasty that had erected them. Some monuments were vandalized and some were moved to new locations. Before its final abandonment all respect for the old rulers had disappeared, with the tombs of the North Acropolis being explored for jade and the easier to find tombs being looted. After 950, Tikal was all but deserted, although a remnant population may have survived in perishable huts interspersed among the ruins. Even these final inhabitants abandoned the city in the 10th or 11th centuries and the rainforest claimed the ruins for the next thousand years. Some of Tikal's population may have migrated to the Peten Lakes region, which remained heavily populated in spite of a plunge in population levels in the first half of the 9th century.

Tikal is one of the most important archaeological sites in Guatemala, dating back to the Neolithic period (5000-10,000 BC).[1] Archaeologists have known for a long time that Tikal was a settlement, but it was not until the mid-twentieth century that an archaeological survey was undertaken in order to map the settlement and excavate it. As a result of this survey, the site was designated a World Heritage Site in 1980 and UNESCO inscribed it on its Unesco World Heritage List in 1986.[2]

Archaeological evidence indicates that Tikal was inhabited as early as 7,000 BC, at the time of the Olmec civilization in Mesoamerica. This period coincides with the rise of the Mayan civilization, which reached its zenith in the second millennium BC. The Maya were renowned for their art, architecture, and religious observances, and many of their temples were built on pyramids, including Teotihuacan, the largest and most well-known of the Maya cities. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The North Acropolis, together with the Great Plaza immediately to the south, is one of the most studied architectural groups in the Maya area ; the Tikal
reference_text: Project excavated a massive trench across the complex, thoroughly investigating its construction history. It is a complex group with construction beginning in the Preclassic Period, around 350 BC. It developed into a funerary complex for the ruling dynasty of the Classic Period, with each additional royal burial adding new temples on top of the older structures. After AD 400 a row of tall pyramids was added to the earlier Northern Platform, which measured 100 by 80 metres ( 330 by 260 ft ), gradually hiding it from view. Eight temple pyramids were built in the 6th century AD, each of them had an elaborate roofcomb and a stairway flanked by masks of the gods. By the 9th century AD, 43 stelae and 30 altars had been erected in the North Acropolis ; 18 of these monuments were carved with hieroglyphic texts and royal portraits. The North Acropolis continued to receive burials into the Postclassic Period.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The Mundo Perdido is to the west of the Plaza of the Seven Temples. It is the largest ceremonial complex dating from the Preclassic period
reference_text: at Tikal. The complex was organized as a large E @-@ Group consisting of a pyramid aligned with a platform to the east that supported three temples. The Mundo Perdido complex was rebuilt many times over the course of its history. By AD 250 – 300 its architectural style was influenced by the great metropolis of Teotihuacan in the Valley of Mexico, including the use of the talud @-@ tablero form. During the Early Classic period ( c. 250 – 600 ) the Mundo Perdido became one of the twin foci of the city, the other being the North Acropolis. From AD 250 to 378 it may have served as the royal necropolis. The Mundo Perdido complex was given its name by the archaeologists of the University of Pennsylvania ; it is centered upon the Lost World Pyramid and a small platform to the west of it.

Discovery and Excavation [ edit ]

Mundo Perdido was discovered in 1881 by William F. O'Callaghan, a New York-based antiquarian with a background in botany. He was on a visit to Mexico when he came across a group of stone carvings that looked like hieroglyphics. After his return to the United States, O'Callaghan made a study of the site, but no one paid much attention to it until the 1930s, when it was rediscovered by an archaeologist named H. A. Wilcox. Wilcox began excavating the site in the summer of 1936, and his work was the first

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> There are nine Twin @-@ Pyramid Complexes at Tikal, one of which was completely dismantled in ancient times and some others were partly destroyed. They
reference_text: vary in size but consist of two pyramids facing each other on an east – west axis. These pyramids are flat @-@ topped and have stairways on all four sides. A row of plain stelae is placed immediately to the west of the eastern pyramid and to the north of the pyramids, and lying roughly equidistant from them, there is usually a sculpted stela and altar pair. On the south side of these complexes there is a long vaulted building containing a single room with nine doorways. The entire complex was built at once and these complexes were built at 20 @-@ year ( or k 'atun ) intervals during the Late Classic. The first twin pyramid complex was built in the early 6th century in the East Plaza. It was once thought that these complexes were unique to Tikal but rare examples have now been found at other sites, such as Yaxha and Ixlu, and they may reflect the extent of Tikal's political dominance in the Late Classic.

Tikal is the largest pre-Columbian Maya city in the world by area and one of the most important archaeological sites in the Americas. It dates to the end of the 13th century, when the Olmecs (Maya rulers) moved south to colonize the area known as El Zotz. This was the first time in Mesoamerica that a city had been built on the Gulf of Mexico.

The pyramid complex consists of nine pyramids, each with a pyramid-shaped spire at its summit. The tallest is the Pyramid of the Sun, which rises 1,500 feet (457 meters) above the surrounding jungle. The second-tallest is the Pyramid of the Moon, which rises 1,200 feet (366 meters) above the jungle. The third-tallest is the Pyramid of the Moon Tiwanaku, which rises 1,100 feet (366 meters) above the jungle. The four smaller pyramids are named after the days of the week, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday.

All of the pyramids are aligned to the cardinal points of the zodiac as well as the solstices and equinoxes. These alignments are thought to have been made by the Maya in order to

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Temple I ( also known as the Temple of Ah Cacao or Temple of the Great Jaguar ) is a funerary pyramid dedicated to Jasaw Chan K
reference_text: 'awil, who was entombed in the structure in AD 734, the pyramid was completed around 740 – 750. The temple rises 47 metres ( 154 ft ) high. The massive roofcomb that topped the temple was originally decorated with a giant sculpture of the enthroned king, although little of this decoration survives. The tomb of the king was discovered by Aubrey Trik of the University of Pennsylvania in 1962. Among items recovered from the Late Classic tomb were a large collection of inscribed human and animal bone tubes and strips with sophisticated scenes depicting deities and people, finely carved and rubbed with vermilion, as well as jade and shell ornaments and ceramic vessels filled with offerings of food and drink. The shrine at the summit of the pyramid has three chambers, each behind the next, with the doorways spanned by wooden lintels fashioned from multiple beams. The outermost lintel is plain but the two inner lintels were carved, some of the beams were removed in the 19th century and their location is unknown, while others were taken to museums in Europe.

Temple I has two pyramids, one of which is over 1,000 feet (305 m) tall and the other of which is over 500 feet (150 m) tall. The pyramid of the Great Jaguar is the largest of the two, although it is dwarfed by the temple of Ah Cacao.

Jasaw Chan Kuei was a warrior-priest and one of the most powerful men in pre-colonial Cambodia. He fought against the Mongols and Huns, as well as his own countrymen, to gain control of the Khmer Empire. After his death, his body was embalmed and placed in the temple, where it remains to this day.

History [ edit ]

Cambodia's history is filled with warring dynasties, political machinations, invasions, revolts, coups de tat, assassinations, and a lot of blood. This has resulted in Cambodia being one of the most ethnically diverse countries in the world. There are three main ethnic groups in Cambodia: the Khmer, the Lao, and the Burmese

edit] History

Aerial view of Temple 33, c. 1550 BC.

The temple was built to commemorate the death of Siyaj Chan K 'awiil I, a pharaoh of the Thutmose III Dynasty who reigned from 1550 to 1450 BC. In order to make it a fitting tribute to his memory, the pyramid was surrounded by a moat and an embankment, as well as a temple of Hathor on the top of the pyramid. At the base of the pyramid was a burial chamber, in which the sarcophagus of Siyaj Chan K 'awiil I was placed. This mausoleum was the first of its kind in Egypt, and remains the only one to have been excavated by archeologists.

The pyramid was destroyed by fire in the reign of Ramses II, and rebuilt several times after that. During the Ptolemaic period, the Great Pyramid of Giza was built on the site of Temple 33, and is thought to have been part of the temple complex. Later, during the Hellenistic period, the Sphinx was moved to the north side of the pyramid for security reasons.

In fact, it has been suggested that the style of the building has closer affinities with El Tajin and Xochicalco than with Teotihuacan itself. The vertical tablero panels are set between sloping talud panels and are decorated with paired disc symbols. Large flower symbols are set into the sloping talud panels, related to the Venus and star symbols used at Teotihuacan. The roof of the structure was decorated with friezes although only fragments now remain, showing a monstrous face, perhaps that of a jaguar, with another head emerging from the mouth. The second head possesses a bifurcated tongue but is probably not that of a snake. The temple, and its associated ballcourt, probably date to the reign of Nuun Ujol Chaak or that of his son Jasaw Chan K 'awiil I, in the later part of the 7th century.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Mount Elbert is part of the Sawatch Range, an uplift of the Laramide Orogeny which separated from the Mosquito Range to the
reference_text: east around 28 million years ago. The tops of this range were heavily glaciated, leaving behind characteristic summit features and other such clues. For example, the base of Elbert on the eastern side exhibits large igneous and metamorphic rocks deposited when the glaciers receded, which lie on a lateral moraine. Further up the eastern side there is a large cirque with a small tarn. There are also lakes to both the north and south, Turquoise and Twin Lakes respectively ; the Twin Lakes are a result of the natural dam of end moraines, and Turquoise Lake was created by the manmade Sugar Loaf Dam.

Geology Edit

Mount Elbert is a subalpine tuff with a composition similar to that of Chugach State Park in Alaska. There are two types of tuff, which are classified as calcareous and metamorphic. Calcareous tuff is composed of silica-rich clays, while metamorphic tuff is composed of feldspar and gypsum. In addition to these, there are a number of igneous rocks such as rhyolite, kimberlite, basalt, schist, and granodiorite. This type of tuff is found in North America, Europe, and Asia.

Climatic and hydrological conditions have changed over the eons, and the mountain has been subjected to glaciation, glacial-interglacial cycles, and volcanism. As a result, the topography of the mountain is characterized by ridges, canyons, escarpments, ravines, and gorges. Most of the mountains in the Sawatch Range are of this type of tuff, as are the Grand Tetons in New York

reference_text: @,@ 440 feet ( 4 @,@ 400 m ) following a re @-@ evaluation of mapped elevations, which sparked protests. The actual change was made in 1988 as a result of the North American Vertical Datum of 1988 ; it seems the original measurement resulted from the Sea Level Datum of 1929. A matter of some contention arose after the Great Depression over the heights of Elbert and its neighbor, Mount Massive, which differ in elevation by only 12 feet ( 3 @.@ 7 m ). This led to an ongoing dispute that came to a head with the Mount Massive supporters building large piles of stones on the summit to boost its height, only to have the Mount Elbert proponents demolish them. The effort was ultimately unsuccessful and Mount Elbert has remained the highest peak in Colorado. The first motorized ascent of Elbert occurred in 1949, when a Jeep was driven to the summit, apparently to judge suitability for skiing development.

If you are planning to spend the night in the mountain, be sure to check in with the ranger station at the trailhead before you leave. It is common for hikers to camp on the trail, but do not leave valuables unattended. Please use common sense and stay on the trail. The weather can change quickly and without warning. It starts at the parking lot just north of the Wabash Trailhead, and ascends a series of switchbacks through a forest of pines and hemlocks. Harvey armour was a type of armour used by the British to protect against shell fire during the Napoleonic Wars. It consisted of a plate of high-tensile steel (HTS) covered with a water-repellent coating. The thickness of the armour was about one-eighth of an inch (0.06 m). In order to provide protection against shrapnel, the front and rear plates were welded together so that the steel remained in contact with the water for a long time. This resulted in a very strong armour plate, but at the same time it was very flimsy and easily punctured. As a result, the armour was designed to be worn over a tunic or other form of undergarment.


At the time of the Battle of Trafalgar, HMS Dorsetshire was the only ship in the Royal Navy equipped with Harvey armour. The British had no choice but to rely on the firepower of the ship's guns to deal with the threat of Napoleon's ships. However, by the time of the Battle of Jutland, there were a number of destroyers and corvettes equipped with Harvey armour, such as HMS Alderney, HMS Amethyst, HMS Astra Zenobia, HMS Ark Royal, HMS Black Prince, HMS De Havilland, HMS Exeter, HMS Foresight

Dego is a master of disguises, which he uses to sneak into places without being noticed. He has a habit of saying "No, I'm not" when asked what he is doing, and his voice is deep and resonant as he does not use a synthesizer. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The 1888 – 89 New Zealand Native football team was a New Zealand rugby union team that toured Britain, Ireland, Australia and New Zealand in 1888 and 1889.
reference_text: It mostly comprised players of Māori ancestry, and also included some Pākehā ( white New Zealanders ). A wholly private endeavour, the tour was not under the auspices of any official rugby authority ; it was organised by New Zealand international player Joseph Warbrick, promoted by civil servant Thomas Eyton, and managed by James Scott, a publican. The Natives were the first New Zealand team to perform a haka, and also the first to wear all black. They played 107 rugby matches during the tour, as well as a small number of Victorian Rules football and association football matches in Australia. Having made a significant impact on the development of New Zealand rugby, the Natives were inducted into the International Rugby Board Hall of Fame in 2008.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Despite his reputation as an artist and seal @-@ carver, Hu was primarily a publisher. His publishing house, the Ten Bamboo Studio, produced
reference_text: reference works on calligraphy, poetry and art ; medical textbooks ; books on etymology and phonetics ; and copies of as well as commentaries on the Confucian Classics. Unlike other publishers in the area, the Ten Bamboo Studio did not publish works of narrative fiction such as plays or novels. This bias towards academia was likely a consequence of the studio's location : the mountain on which Hu took up residence was just to the north of the Nanjing Guozijian ( National Academy ), which provided a captive market for academic texts. Between 1627 and 1644, the Ten Bamboo Studio produced over twenty printed books of this kind, aimed at a wealthy, literary audience. The studio's earliest publications were medical textbooks, the first of which, Tested Prescriptions for Myriad Illnesses ( Wanbing Yanfang, 萬病驗方 ) was published in 1631 and proved popular enough to be reissued ten years later. Hu's brother Zhengxin was a medical practitioner and appears to have been the author of these books.

As a publisher, Hu maintained a low profile, preferring to stay out of the limelight. This did not stop him from making a name for himself in the 1920s and 1930s, however, when he became the first Chinese poet to receive the Nobel Prize in Literature. In addition to his award, Hu was awarded the Order of Merit of the People's Republic of China, the highest honor bestowed by the government on a Chinese citizen. This accolade was the culmination of a long career of public service, beginning with his appointment as a civil servant in the Kuomintang government in 1921. By the time he took up the position of poet laureate in 1929, Hu had risen to the rank of generalissimo in the Kuomintang Literary Bureau, a position he held until his death in 1940.

In the mid-1630s the Ten Bamboo Studio moved to an area of the Forbidden City known as the "Wu-tang Room" to avoid being seen as a rival to the more well-known Studio of the Emperor Yongle. This was the time of the Qianlong Emperor, who reigned from 1636 to 1695. It was during this period that the Ten Bamboo Studio began to produce a wide variety of painting, engraving, and calligraphy masterpieces. Among the works produced by the Ten Bamboo Studio during this period are the portraits of Confucius, Lao-tzu, and Sun Yat-sen. One of the most famous works of the Ten Bamboo Studio is the "Dalai Lama" (普宗寺), which was painted in 1636 and has been in the collection of the National Palace Museum in Beijing since its acquisition in the early twentieth century. The title refers to the Dalai Lama of Tibet, who was exiled to India in 1959 after a failed uprising against Chinese rule. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The Ming dynasty had seen considerable advancement in the process of colour printing in China. At his studio, Hu Zhengyan experimented with various forms of woodblock printing
reference_text: , creating processes for producing multi @-@ coloured prints and embossed printed designs. As a result, he was able to produce some of China's first printed publications in colour, using a block printing technique known as " assorted block printing " ( douban yinshua, 饾板印刷 ). This system made use of multiple blocks, each carved with a different part of the final image and each bearing a different colour. It was a lengthy, painstaking process, requiring thirty to fifty engraved printing blocks and up to seventy inkings and impressions to create a single image. Hu also employed a related form of multiple @-@ block printing called " set @-@ block printing " ( taoban yinshua, 套板印刷 ), which had existed since the Yuan period some 200 years earlier but had only recently come into fashion again. He refined these block printing techniques by developing a process for wiping some of the ink off the blocks before printing ; this enabled him to achieve gradation and modulation of shades which were not previously possible.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Hu's most notable work is the Ten Bamboo Studio Manual of Painting and Calligraphy ( Shizhuzhai Shuhuapu,
reference_text: 十竹齋書畫譜 ), an anthology of around 320 prints by around thirty different artists ( including Hu himself ), published in 1633. It consists of eight sections, covering calligraphy, bamboo, flowers, rocks, birds and animals, plums, orchids and fruit. Some of these sections had been released previously as single volumes. As well as a collection of artworks, it was also intended as an artistic primer, with instructions on correct brush position and technique and several pictures designed for beginners to copy. Although these instructions only appear in the sections on orchids and bamboo, the book still remains the first example of a categorical and analytical approach to Chinese painting. In this book, Hu used his multiple @-@ block printing methods to obtain gradations of colour in the images, rather than obvious outlines or overlaps. The manual is bound in the " butterfly binding " ( hudie zhuang, 蝴蝶裝 ) style, whereby whole @-@ folio illustrations are folded so that each occupies a double @-@ page spread. This binding style allows the reader to lay the book flat in order to look at a particular image. Cambridge University Library released a complete digital scan of the manual, including all writings and illustrations in August, 2015. Said Charles Aylmer, Head of the Cambridge University Chinese Department, " The binding is so fragile, and the manual so delicate, that until it was digitized, we have never been able to let anyone look through it or study it – despite its undoubted importance to scholars. Hu Zhiyong (1898-1972) was a well-known sculptor and calligrapher in China. He studied at the Kunming Conservatory of Fine Arts and received his M.A. in Art in 1922. His career spanned more than 50 years and during that time he produced more than 1,000 calligraphy and engraving works. Most of his works were based on nature and the human body. In the 1930s and 1940s, he began to experiment with painting and the use of collage as a means of expression. After the Cultural Revolution of the 1960s, Hu Zhiyong moved to Hong Kong and lived there until his death in 1972.

Spain had transformed from an ally of Great Britain in the War of the First Coalition into an enemy in 1796. Thus the presence of a powerful Spanish squadron at Manila posed a threat to the China Fleet, an annual convoy of East Indiaman merchant ships from Macau in Qing Dynasty China to Britain, which was of vital economic importance to Britain. Background Edit

The raid was carried out by a fleet of French warships under the command of Admiral Jules-Antoine de Bougainville, who was in the process of setting up a base in the Philippines. On January 1798, Bougainville's fleet sailed from Malacca en route to Manila, which was at the time under the control of the Spanish governor-general Pedro Menéndez de Avilés. After an abortive attempt to land at Corregidor, the admiral decided to make a detour to Subic Bay, a strait between Manila and Mindanao (Philippines). This was the first time in the history of the French naval forces that they had taken part in a naval war without the support of a land army.

Bougainville's fleet consisted of two frigates, a frigate-carrier, and an amphibious warship. The French navy did not have the ships in the Mediterranean and North African theatres that were essential for the operation, such as the Dunkerque, Le Havre, Montcalm, St. Nazaire, Orléans, and Toulon battlegroups. What was the Treaty of San Ildefonso?

The Treaty of San Ildefonso was signed on July 17, 1796, by Spain and France to end the French Revolution. At the time, Spain was a member of the U.S. confederation, and France was a sovereign nation in its own right. This meant that each country had the right to send troops to any other country without the consent of the other country. As a result, there was a lot of fighting between the two countries, which resulted in the Napoleonic Wars.

The signing of the Treaty of San Ildefonso was the brainchild of Napoleon Bonaparte, who was the First Consul of France. His goal was to reunite France and Spain, which had been at war since 1795. The Treaty of Paris was signed in 1783 and its stipulations laid out the terms under which the US would cede Puerto Rico, Guam, Saipan and the Philippines to Spain. As well as the land, the treaty stipulated that there would be "no molestation of the inhabitants, nor any of their civil or religious rights, as they have at present" and that Spanish subjects would be allowed to carry arms without hindrance.

Founding Edit

Main article: Founding of the China Fleet

The China Fleet was founded in 1798 by Rear Admiral Zheng Zuolin, a native of Fujian Province, who was in command of the newly-arrived battleship Hsien-shu. As well as Zheng, the fleet consisted of a fleet of smaller frigates, corvettes, destroyers, sloops, yachts, schooners, trawlers, barges, pinnaces, gunboats, rafts, canoes, and fishing boats. These vessels were armed with muskets, flintlock revolvers, powder kegs, ballistae, mortars, grapeshot, and bayonets. [1]

Mission Edit

Main article: Battle of Port Moresby

At the Battle of Port Moresby in 1798, the China Fleet took part in the attack on the British frigate HMS Erebus, which was escorting convoys to Timor. The Erebus was sunk by a salvo of cannon fire from the China Fleet's guns, and its crew became prisoners of war. After the

History of the Campaign

The war in the Pacific was in its third year, and the United States and the Soviet Union were at loggerheads over the control of the Pacific. Japanese strategists felt that it was their duty to drive the Americans out of the Far East as quickly as possible, and this was the reason for their invasion of the Philippines in December 1941. As a result, the Japanese planned a three-pronged attack: land invasion, air attack, and naval blockade. These three phases were to be carried out in the order of their priority, and the first two phases were to be combined into one, known as the Ketsu Go (Cease Fire).

Okinawa as a Naval Base

During the war, Okinawa was home to the Navy's Fifth Fleet, which had been based there since its creation in the 1930s. The Okinawa-based Fifth Fleet played a major role in the Battle of Midway in 1942 and the invasion of Guadalcanal in 1943. In addition, the carrier-based Fifth Fleet provided air support for the landings on Iwo Jima and Okinawa, and, for a time, served as the base for the Pacific Fleet. As late as 1944, the Fifth Fleet operated out of Yokosuka, Japan, a short distance from Okinawa.

Arnhem was a relatively small town of 2,000 or so in the Netherlands Antilles, about halfway between Curacao and Martinique. It was an important staging area for U.S. forces in the Pacific and had been the scene of a number of skirmishes between Japanese and Allied navies over the years. On the night of 22 May, the Japanese launched a surprise attack on the garrison, killing or wounding many of the men and setting fire to the town. In the confusion, one of the ships in the anchorage, the battleship Musashi, ran aground and was scuttled by the Dutch and British forces. The battle lasted two days and resulted in the loss of at least two destroyers and a supply ship. By the end of the day, the town was in flames and all that remained of the Japanese was a smoldering hulk of a sunken battleship.


As news of the battle spread, it became clear that the Japanese had no intention of surrendering. After much indecision, Prime Minister Hideki Tojo of Japan made the decision to capitulate and was taken into custody by the United States Marine Corps. His surrender speech was broadcast over the radio and received a rousing reception in the United States.

Controls

Sonic is controlled with the WASD keys, and in Super Sonic and Super Sonic 2, the Z and X keys. In Classic Sonic, the player can switch between the two at any time by pressing the space bar. However, this does not work in all levels, due to technical limitations.

Movement

As Sonic runs, he accelerates, decelerates, and changes direction in mid-air. The game keeps track of how fast Sonic is moving, and this is used to determine the height of the jump he can perform. For example, if Sonic is running at 1.5 m/s, and jumps a height of 2 m, he will land on the ground at the same height as he started.

Speed

Every run has a time limit, which is displayed in the top-left corner of the screen. The time limit is reset to 0:00 at the start of every level. When the time limit is reached, the player is teleported to the title screen, and the game restarts from the beginning. This makes it possible to get a high score, but it also means that the levels

Design Edit

The game began with concept art, which was used to determine the size of the game world, terrain, and other elements. These concepts were then turned into 3D models and textured in Blender. In-game models were created by animators, who had to be paid in gold for their work. Some of the most well-known characters in the game were based on real-life animals, such as the giraffe, ostrich, zebra, cheetah, hippopotamus, rhinoceros, leopard, and crocodile.

Gameplay Edit

AM8 was the first game to use motion capture technology, which allowed players to walk, run, crouch, and perform acrobatic maneuvers by mimicking the movements of animal characters. These motion capture animations were then incorporated into the game's physics engine, which allowed the game to be played in real-time. For example, a player could throw a boomerang at an enemy, and the boomerang would ricochet off the enemy and hit the player in the back of the head. Another example would be the use of firebombs, which could be

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Sonic was originally teal @-@ colored, then a light shade of blue, but he was changed to dark blue so he would stand out against certain
reference_text: backgrounds and to match the Sega logo. His shoes were colored red through the inspiration of Michael Jackson's boots on the album cover for Bad and the outfit of Santa Claus, whom Ohshima saw as the most " famous character in the world ". Sonic's spikes were emphasized to make him look sleeker, and he was given the ability to spin while jumping ( so attacking and jumping could be controlled with one button ). The new character was originally named " Mr. Needlemouse ", but the eight @-@ member AM8 changed his name to " Sonic " and their studios to Sonic Team. Ideas proposed to flesh out the character included placing him in a rock band, giving him vampire fangs, and giving him a human girlfriend named Madonna, but Sega of America scrapped these ideas to keep his identity simple. Sega of America also expressed concerns that most Americans would not know what a hedgehog is and initially proposed a full @-@ scale recreation of the character, but compromised with Sonic Team to simply make design changes. The antagonist ended up being named " Dr. Eggman " in Japan and " Dr. Robotnik " in other regions as a result of a dispute between Sega's American and Japanese divisions.

Sonic has an interesting and somewhat-complicated history with color. When he was first introduced in the '80s, he was supposed to be a blue-and-purple hedgehog with a red "glow" in his eyes. That was the original design, and it stayed that way for a long time. However, Sega of America (the company that owns the rights to Sonic) wanted to change the color of Sonic to something more "mainstream" for the game, and they came up with the idea of him being teal. The problem was that blue was the color of blood, and blood is associated with death in a lot of cultures. This caused a lot of controversy, and in the end, Sonic was changed to his current color scheme.

The gameplay originated with a tech demo by Naka, who developed an algorithm allowing a sprite to move smoothly on a curve by determining its position with a dot matrix. Naka's prototype was a platform game with a fast @-@ moving character rolling in a ball through a long, winding tube, and this concept was fleshed out with Ohshima's character designs and levels by designer Hirokazu Yasuhara. Yasuhara originally intended to work on the game for three months due to the delay of his planned move to the United States by the outbreak of the Gulf War, but was engrossed in the project for nearly a year. His designs for levels were intended to attract both hardcore and casual gamers by integrating occasional challenging set pieces into the mostly accessible level design. The game's color scheme was influenced by the work of pop artist Eizin Suzuki, and the aesthetics of Green Hill were influenced by the geography of California.

This is an excerpt from a feature I wrote for Game Informer in which I talk about the development of Golden Axe: The Fighting Game of the Sixties. You can read the full article here.

It was one of the most ambitious games Sega ever made. Released in the summer of '66, Golden Axe was a two-player brawler where you fought to the death in a labyrinth of mazes filled with bad guys. Each character had a unique move set, and the game featured over a dozen enemy types ranging from fire-breathing dragons to robot centipedes. There was so much going on in such a small space that it was hard to keep track of all the intricacies at first.

Sega's marketing materials made it sound like this was the pinnacle of fighting games, but that was far from the truth. At the time, the genre was in its infancy, and many of the game's design decisions were based on feedback from arcade players. For example, the character selection screen was split into two sections, one for each player. In the top half, you could select up to four characters, and in the bottom half, you could select up to four more. This was a design

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> In designing the game mechanics, Naka was inspired by Shigeru Miyamoto, whose games he had enjoyed playing years earlier. Admiring the simplicity
reference_text: of Miyamoto's mechanics in complex environments, Naka decided that Sonic would be controlled with only a directional pad for movement and a single button for jumping. He also wanted his creation to be more action @-@ oriented than the Mario series ; while playing Super Mario Bros., he had wondered why the levels could not be cleared more quickly. Due to the need to demonstrate the Genesis'technological prowess, the developing game underwent extensive testing and redesign, a process taking over six months. The developers'efforts were rewarded ; according to Yuji Naka, the game had the fastest @-@ ever character speed in a video game and a rotation effect in the special stages that was considered impossible on the console. The team intended to add a two @-@ player mode displayed via split @-@ screen, but Naka's programming knowledge was insufficient to implement this feature. However, such a mode would later appear in sequel Sonic the Hedgehog 2 ( 1992 ), where the second player would control Sonic's best friend Miles " Tails " Prower. Naka, Oshima, and Yasuhara worked 19 hours a day on the project for several months.

This article is part of Polygon's Game Design series. Check out the rest of the series here.

One of the most important things to keep in mind when designing a game is that there is no such thing as a "perfect" game. You have to make trade-offs, and that's the best way to learn the game. It's like cooking a meal: the more ingredients you put in, the more complicated it is to come up with a good dish. In the same way, games are made up of a lot of elements, and each of them has a role to play. Some are essential, like story and gameplay. Others are there to fill niches, like visual design and music. Still others are a byproduct of the game's design, like level design and user interface.

As a designer, you need to figure out what elements are going to be in your game, and how they're going to be used. For example, let's say you're designing a first-person shooter (FPS). The player is shooting a character in a 3D environment, and that character is moving around using a joystick. How are you going to make the player feel like they're in control? What's the best way to convey that to the player?

It was originally intended to have a sound test menu with animations of Sonic breakdancing to the music of a " Sonic Band " of Sharps Chicken on guitar, Max Monkey on bass, Mach Rabbit on drums, and Vector the Crocodile on keyboard. The playable Vector became a recurring character in the series, also appearing in Knuckles'Chaotix, Sonic Heroes, and Sonic Free Riders. The development schedule scrapped the feature, and Yuji Naka replaced the test with the " Se @-@ ga! " chant used in TV commercials ( which reportedly used one @-@ eighth of the memory of the four @-@ megabit cartridge ).

Biography

Nakamura grew up in Shizuoka Prefecture, Japan with his parents, who were in the service of the U.S. Air Force. As a child, he played the trombone and flute, and in high school took part in marching band competitions. After graduating from high school, he went to Tokyo University of the Arts (Toukyou) to study music composition and orchestration. While at Toukyou, he met Takashi Iizuka, who was a student there at the time. The two became friends and began jamming together, developing a love for each other's music. During this time, Nakamura had the opportunity to work with Tetsuya Komuro, one of the composers of the Mega Man series, on a project called "Avalon of the Spheres" (空の輝き, Seitai no Kiki).[1] Komuro's music was used as the theme for the video game Super Robot Taisen OG Saga: Eternal Wings and the Lost Ocean, and the soundtrack for the Sega Saturn/Megadrive game Space Harrier X: Mirai Fukuin Densetsu. This was the first time that an American-Japanese collaboration had been made in video game music. It was also the first time that a videogame composer had received a Grammy

reference_text: " finish them neatly ". According to Watanabe, the developers asked him to create a package design " similar to pop art... without being particular to conventional packages " – something " original " and " stylish ". The game was released in North America, Europe, and Australia on June 23, 1991, and in Japan on July 26. Sega of America packaged it with American Genesis consoles, replacing Altered Beast. Genesis owners who bought their consoles before the switch could request free copies of Sonic the Hedgehog by mail. Sega of America created a large @-@ scale marketing campaign to promote the game and Sonic as a mascot for the company.

Gameplay

Sonic the Hedgehog is a side-scrolling platformer where the player controls Sonic the Hedgehog, a character from the Sonic the Hedgehog series. There are two types of levels: 1-1 and 1-2. The first level is based on the opening cutscene of Sonic the Hedgehog, while the second level is based on the game's boss, Knuckles the Echidna. Both levels take place in Dr. Eggman's base, and have to be completed in a certain time or you lose the game.

Sonic's story takes place in a world where time is cycled, which means you have to make your way through time by collecting rings and avoiding baddies. The player starts with a pair of shoes that act as a time machine, and each level is broken up into a series of "chapters" that give you a chance to pick up new abilities and power-ups. There are a lot of collectibles along the way, and it's up to you to figure out how to get them all.

As well as playing as Sonic, you can switch between him and Tails at any time. Tails is a speedster with a propeller on his back, and he can jump higher and carry more rings. In addition to this, he can transform into a jetpack and take to the skies for a bit of high-speed chases. Both characters have their own level of speed, and each comes with their own special moves.
