Sonic was one of the first games to use 3D graphics, and it's no surprise that so many people were drawn to the game for its graphics. In an interview with Polygon, game designer Yuji Naka talked about the creation of the game's graphics, and how they were based on the Sega Genesis and Megadrive.

"There was a lot of discussion about how to make Sonic look good on the Genesis," Naka said. "At the time, I was working on Mega Man 2, and that was the first game that I designed from scratch. I had an idea in my head of what I wanted to do, and I started sketching on napkins and making mock-ups of the character in the middle of the night. The next morning, I went to work and got to work right away. After that, I spent a lot of time trying to come up with a design that would be easy to animate and use the Genesis' capabilities as well as it could."

Sonic was the first video game character to have his own comic book series, written by Mark Evanier and pencilled by Tom Scioli. The series ran for 52 issues from 1992 to 1995, and was followed by a spin-off miniseries, Sonic the Hedgehog: Chaotix, which ran for a total of four issues (in addition to the series' run-up to the game's release). This mini-series ended in 1996, with the cancellation of the series due to financial problems.

"Saturn Bomberman"), and was intended to be a spiritual successor to the Super Mario Bros. series. Synopsis Edit

A group of high school students go to a movie that turns out to be a reenactment of the Battle of Gettysburg. As the night goes on, tensions rise between the students and the townspeople, who have no idea what is going on. NEW YORK (AP) — The father of a New York teenager who died after inhaling carbon monoxide from a concertgoer's cigarette has filed a wrongful death lawsuit against the club that hosted the event.

Lawyers for the Rev. Blythe Tinsley, an Anglican minister who officiated at the May 24, 2010, concert at the Prague club Abaton, say the club failed to provide adequate ventilation and did not warn concertgoers about the dangers of smoking in the club.

Tinsley's lawsuit seeks unspecified damages for the teen's death, which was ruled a suicide by the medical examiner's office.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The route of what became US 2 was used as part of two Indian trails before European settlers came to the UP, and as part of the Michigan segments of

The state later included these trails as part of M ‑ 12 when the first state highway trunklines were designated in 1919. Most of M ‑ 12 was redesignated as part of US 2 when the US Highway System was created on November 11, 1926. Since the 1930s, several changes have reshaped the highway's routing through the UP. One such alteration eventually created a business loop that connected across the state line with Hurley, Wisconsin, and others pushed an originally inland routing of US 2 closer to the Lake Michigan shoreline. With the creation of the Interstate Highway System, part of US 2 was rerouted to coincide with the new Interstate 75 ( I ‑ 75 ), though in the 1980s, the U.S. Highway was truncated and removed from the I ‑ 75 freeway, resulting in today's basic form.

To deal with the backlog of accidents, the Missouri Department of Transportation (MDOT) began construction of what is now I-44, a multi-lane highway that bypasses the bottleneck by going through Kansas City, Overland Park, Olathe, Leawood, Lenexa, Topeka, Salina, Shawnee, and Wichita.

A little more than a year later, on July 1, 1925, the road was renamed in honor of the man who made it possible by inventing the air conditioner. That would be John A. Macomber, an engineer and philanthropist who helped bring electricity to Michigan in the 1880s.

It's no surprise that Michigan's most famous road is named after a man who played a role in the state's founding. But what is surprising is that the name has been in use for more than 100 years without anyone thinking to change it.

According to the Michigan Department of Transportation, there are at least two theories as to why the road was named after Macomber. One is that his name was the first to be engraved on the road, which is located in St. Clair County, north of Traverse City. The other is that the county had a law forbidding the renaming of roads after non-residents.

Whatever the reason, no one has taken the road's name in the past two decades. That's the good news. The bad news is that, in all likelihood, we'll have to wait until 2040 to see the road re-named.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> In December 2012, the National Park Service approved the listing of the Upper Twin Falls Bridge that crosses the Menominee River northwest of Iron Mountain. The

On April 1, 2013, the NPS will take another step toward listing the bridge as a Superfund site. That's when the agency will decide whether to move forward with a permit application to dredge the bridge, an action that would cost at least $1 million.

According to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, there are no regulations in place that require the bridge to be dredged. Dredging is a process that uses explosives to dislodge sediment and fill in potholes that result from construction of roadways, bridges and other structures.

In order to make the bridge navigable, the bridge needs to be raised to a height of 30 feet above the river and have a deck that is at least 1 foot thick. It also needs to be able to withstand a wind of 100 mph (160 kph), which is the speed at which the river is flowing at the time of the bridge's construction.

If the bridge is listed as a Superfund site, the cost of remediation would be borne by the State of Wisconsin, which would have to pay for the work in the long term. However, as of right now, the state is on the hook for no more than $500,000 a year for the next 10 years

reference_text: Built as a part of a raceway flume on the river, the water level is actually higher than the road surface. This produces a siphon effect, giving the bridge its nickname. The Manistique Pulp and Paper Company was organized in 1916 and needed a dam on the Manistique River to supply their mill. This dam would require a large section of the city to be flooded, and shallow river banks meant difficulties in any bridge construction. Instead of expensive dikes, a concrete tank was built lengthwise in the river bed ; the sides of this tank provided man @-@ made banks higher than the natural banks. The Michigan Works Progress Administration described the bridge as having " concrete bulkheads, formed by the side spans of the bridge, [ that ] allow the mill to maintain the water level several feet above the roadbed. " The Manistique Tourism Council stated : " At one time, the bridge itself was partially supported by the water that was atmospherically forced under it, " and that the bridge has been featured in Ripley's Believe It or Not!. The eight @-@ span structure is 294 feet ( 90 m ) long.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Since her debut in 1990, Carey had not journeyed on a large or extensive tour. In fact, she had not embarked on a tour until her third
reference_text: studio effort, Music Box ( 1993 ), when she performed six arena shows in the United States during the Music Box Tour. The opening night of the tour received scathing reviews, mostly aimed at Carey's deemed " obvious " stage @-@ fright and failure to make a connection with the crowd. Succeeding nights were more favorably reviewed, with critics raving about Carey's vocals. Jon Pareles of The New York Times wrote regarding Carey's live vocals, " Beyond any doubt, Ms. Carey's voice is no studio concoction. Her range extends from a rich, husky alto to dog @-@ whistle high notes ; she can linger over sensual turns, growl with playful confidence, syncopate like a scat singer. " However, after the strong media attention, Carey did not visit the US on her succeeding Daydream World Tour in 1996, visiting only Europe and Asia. The tour in contrast, received critical acclaim from critics and fans alike, as well as breaking ticket sale records. Carey's three shows at Japan's largest stadium, Tokyo Dome, sold out in under three hours, equaling in over 150 @,@ 000 tickets, setting the record of fastest show sellouts in Japan's history. On the Butterfly World Tour, Carey broke the record, selling 200 @,@ 000 tickets in under one hour. During 1997, after the commercially and critically successful release of Butterfly, Carey had not planned to tour once again, due to the long travel times and strain on her voice. However, due to overwhelming demand by fans, Carey agreed to perform in Asia once again, only extending the tour to Taiwan and Australia, as well as one last show in the United States. Rehearsals for the show began shortly after Christmas 1997, extending for a period of two weeks.

album, The Emancipation of Mimi, which was released in 1994. This would be the first of many years of non-tour activity for Carey, a fact that many fans found baffling at the time.

Carey's decision to go on a tour was met with mixed reactions from fans, some of whom felt that it was a step backwards for her, while others were eager to see her perform in their hometowns. As time went on, the tour became a source of controversy, not only due to the number of cancellations, but also because of Carey's performance at the Lollapalooza festival in Chicago, which was marred by a protest by Black Lives Matter activists.

On the other hand, there were those who found solace in the fact that Carey was no longer making music for the radio, but for the masses. With the release of her fourth album, Dreaming Out Loud, Carey began to take her music to a new level of popularity, and it was this album that cemented her place as one of the most popular artists of the 1990s.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The windmill at Thelnetham was built by millwright George Bloomfield for William Button in 1819. It replaced a post mill which had been
reference_text: moved to Sandy Lane, Diss, Norfolk the previous year. The mill was set to work on Christmas Day 1819. In 1832, the mill was modernised by the fitting of a cast @-@ iron windshaft, Patent sails and a fantail. The new windshaft was fitted on 16 July 1832. It was made by J Aickman, the Kings Lynn millwright, and weighs 1 ¾ tons ( 1 @,@ 780 kg ). A new stock was fitted in September 1836. William Button died on 11 February 1837. The mill passed jointly to his widow Rebecca and their son Richard. Richard Button worked the mill until 1860, at which date it was conveyed to his sons Richard and William, who sold it to Richard Peverett from Kenninghall, Norfolk in 1862.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The mill was worked by Stephen Peverett, Richard's son. He inherited the mill on the death of his father in 1875 and leased it to
reference_text: Henry Bryant in 1879. In 1884, the mill was sold by auction, and Henry Bryant purchased the freehold. Bryant rebuilt the floors of the mill. From 1892, a portable steam engine was used as auxiliary power, driving an extra pair of millstones on the ground floor. This was replaced in 1914 by a Hornsby oil engine. Bryant ran the mill until 1920 when he sold it to Alphonso Vincent, a retired millwright from Garboldisham, Norfolk. The Hornsby engine was sold in the early 1920s. The mill was tailwinded c1920, and as a result one pair of sails was removed. Vincent carried out some repairs to the mill and ran it until he retired in 1924. One of the remaining two sails was wrecked in 1926 when the mill was again tailwinded.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> From 1870 until 1901, each of the six colonial governments was responsible for their own defence. The colonies had gained responsible government between 1855 and 1890, and
reference_text: while the Colonial Office in London retained control of some affairs, the Governor of the each colony was required to raise their own colonial militia. To do this, they were granted the authority from the British crown to raise military and naval forces. Initially these were militias in support of British regulars, but when military support for the colonies ended in 1870, the colonies assumed their own defence responsibilities. The colonial military forces included unpaid volunteer militia, paid citizen soldiers, and a small permanent component. They were mainly infantry, cavalry and mounted infantry, and were neither housed in barracks nor subject to full military discipline. Even after significant reforms in the 1870s — including the expansion of the permanent forces to include engineer and artillery units — they remained too small and unbalanced to be considered armies in the modern sense. By 1885, the forces numbered 21 @,@ 000 men. Although they could not be compelled to serve overseas many volunteers subsequently did see action in a number conflicts of the British Empire during the 19th century, with the colonies raising contingents to serve in Sudan, South Africa and China.

Battle of Arnhem Land

Arnhem Land was a land battle fought between the British and the Germans in the Netherlands East Indies (now Indonesia). The battle was an amphibious assault on the heavily fortified Dutch fortifications at Arnhem, which was part of the German-occupied Netherlands East Indies. The Germans hoped to gain control of the strategically important island of Java, which was vital to the German war effort. After months of planning, the assault began on the night of 25–26 June 1915. In the early hours of the morning, over a thousand German paratroopers jumped from aircraft and landed on the beach, taking up positions in the village of Amersfoort. At 0600 hours, the British landings began and within an hour had succeeded in dislodging the Germans from the area. By this time, it was clear that the Germans were no match for the British, who had more than twice the number of troops to the Germans' one. The Boxer Rebellion is one of the most well-known examples of foreign intervention in China's internal affairs. However, there is little to be gained from looking at the history of the Boxer Rebellion as a case study in foreign intervention, at least in the sense that it is the only example of foreign intervention in China's internal affairs that we know of. This new force also lacked blue water capable ships, and ultimately did not lead to a change in Australian naval policy. The Admiralty rejected and resented the challenge, but suggested diplomatically that a small fleet of destroyers and submarines would be sufficient. The Anzacs were one of the most successful units of the New Zealand Army, and played a major part in the Gallipoli campaign of 1915-16. A total of 2,619 Kiwi soldiers lost their lives in the First World War, compared to a death toll of 1,814 for the British and 7,564 for the Australians. This was the highest proportion of New Zealanders to war casualties in the world at the time. It was also the first time that a nation had fought two wars in one war.

This paved the way for the BEF to advance to the Rhine River and, later, to the Elbe River. Brookes argues that the failure of the war was a factor in the party's loss of the 1945 election, and his conclusions are in line with those of Australian historian Andrew MacDougall-Shirreff, who points out that the "lack of a mass movement against the war led to the defeat of the left in the 1945 election" (MacDougall-Shirreff, 2004, p. xi).

As well as the SWP, the left-wing of the ALP had its own anti-war movement, the War Resisters League (WRL), which organised in the 1930s and 1940s. Australia's involvement in the Vietnam War was short-lived, lasting no more than two years. After the withdrawal of Australian troops in 1973, there was no need for a strategic reserve, and the war ended without Australia fighting a major war.

Prior to World War II, Australia had been a neutral country for the majority of its history. This changed in the 1930s, when the Japanese invaded Manchuria and established a puppet government in Nanjing. Synopsis Edit

Comedian Marc Wilmore takes on the role of Rob Lowe, one of the most polarizing figures in Hollywood. In an effort to find out what it's like to be a celebrity, Marc travels to Los Angeles to sit in the audience at a roast of Rob Lowe. Along the way, he gets to know the roasters and tries to make a joke or two of his own. This is the first episode of a two-part series that will air in the fall of 2013.

Recap Edit

Part 1 Edit

The night before the roast, Stephen Colbert is on stage talking about his love of roast jokes. He says that he has a few in his back pocket, but they're not going to be used tonight. As he walks off the stage, a crowd of about 1,000 people begins to boo and jeer, much to Colbert's chagrin. After some huffing and puffing, Colbert returns to the stage and delivers his monologue. During the joke, he makes a reference to The Godfather, where Marlon Brando's character "Marlon Bruere" asks the audience to raise their hands if they're in the Mafia. The crowd goes wild in response. Later, Stephen's co-host Jon Stewart comes out to apologize for the booing.

Homer is on the phone with his wife Marge, lamenting about the state of the world. They go on to reminisce about their wedding day, which was in the middle of a blizzard. As an afterthought, Homer asks Marge if she would like to be a snow queen for the winter solstice. This is a reference to the episode "Treehouse of Horror XXVIII", in which Mr. Burns attempts to create a world-wide snow queen by giving each of his employees a costume made of snowflakes.

After some back and forth, the phone cuts out mid-sentence, and Homer gets up to change the channel. While doing so, he bumps into Ned Flanders, who has fallen asleep on the couch. Homer apologizes for bumping into him, and Flanders says that he's had a rough day of work. Homer tries to make light of the situation by pointing out that there's no time to be having a "rough day of work" when it's snowing outside. reference_text: " ) and the University of Cambridge ( sometimes referred to as the " Light Blues " ). First held in 1829, the race takes place on the 4 @.@ 2 @-@ mile ( 6 @.@ 8 km ) Championship Course on the River Thames in southwest London. The rivalry is a major point of honour between the two universities and followed throughout the United Kingdom and broadcast worldwide. Cambridge went into the race as reigning champions, having beaten Oxford by over a length in the previous year's race and the overall lead, with 79 victories to Oxford's 73. The race was sponsored by Xchanging for the fourth time.

Boat Race rules

1. No boats larger than 25m (82ft) are allowed.

2. Rowers must be 18 years or older.

3. A minimum of two oarsmen is required for each boat.

4. There is no penalty for oversteering, but it is an offence to make a manoeuvre that results in a bow wave.

5. The course is divided into sections that are marked by buoys. At the start of each section, the boat is allowed to pass a buoy that indicates the direction of the section. This is to make it easier for the rowers to orientate themselves in the wind and keep an eye on the course.

6. All boats must have a headlamp on at all times.

7. Boat speed is limited to a maximum of 10 knots (15km/h).

8. If a boat collides with another boat, the collision is to be penalised by disqualification.

9. Any infractions of the rules will result in a reprimand from the Head Coach

AdvertisementsAs the world's most popular cryptocurrency, Bitcoin has come a long way since its inception in 2009. In this article, we look at the history of Bitcoin, what it is, and how it works.

What is Bitcoin?

Bitcoin is a peer-to-peer cryptocurrency that allows users to send and receive payments without the need for a third party. Instead, Bitcoin uses a network of computers to verify transactions, known as the blockchain. The blockchain is a public ledger of all Bitcoin transactions that have taken place so far. Each Bitcoin transaction is cryptographically signed by the user's private key, which is stored on the user's computer. This prevents double spending, the act of spending the same Bitcoin twice.

Who invented Bitcoin?

On April 1, 1842, some soldiers of Fort Wayne left their fort and on April 22 arrived where Fort Scott would be built, in the Osage Cuestas section of modern @-@ day Kansas. Chickamauga was an unincorporated territory of the Cherokee Nation at the time of the 1816 Treaty of Greenville, which ceded the land west of the Tennessee River to the United States in return for $10,000 per year to be spent on education and military fortifications. This stipulation was the first of many that would come to define the relationship between the Cherokees and the United States, and one of the most important was the removal of the Cherokee from their homelands and resettling them in what would become the state of Tennessee.


As time went on, the number of Cherokee who lived in Chickamauga grew to over 100,000 (compared to less than 1,000 in the 1790 census) and it became the largest city in the Cherokee Nation. By the mid-1820s, there were as many as 30,000 people living in the city, a number that would continue to grow over the next 50 years. This growth was in part due to the development of railroads, which allowed people to travel great distances without having to travel by horse or foot. In 1832, the railroad was extended to the east, connecting Chickamauga with Knoxville, Tennessee

Early History

The land on which Fort Sumter was built was known as Roanoke Island, a name given to it by Thomas Jefferson in 1784. At that time, Virginia was the only state in the United States with a military presence on the mainland. Jefferson's plan was to create a base for the newly formed United States Army in the Carolinas, and it was decided that the fort would be built on Roanoke Island. Construction began in 1785, and the fort was completed in 1786. During the Revolutionary War, the fort served as a training center for the Continental Army. After the war, the fort was decommissioned and turned into a Civil War reenactment site. In 1864, President Abraham Lincoln signed the Emancipation Proclamation, freeing all slaves in the United States. On January 1, 1865, the Union Army marched into Charleston, South Carolina, and took control of the city. In the Battle of Fort Sumter, the Union Army suffered a crushing defeat, and was forced to surrender. Confederate General Robert E. Lee surrendered

In a King of the Mountain match, the objective is to climb a ladder and hang the championship belt on a hook above the ring. In order to do so, a wrestler must first qualify by either pinning or making another wrestler submit in the match. A wrestler who is pinned or made to submit is this placed in a penalty box for two minutes. The match is fought under no disqualification rules. Nash stopped him and then dropped Booker T back @-@ first against the mat with his signature Jackknife Powerbomb maneuver. Joe was the last to qualify by pinning Roode after slamming him back and neck @-@ first into the mat with his signature Muscle Buster maneuver. Joe then hung the title belt at 19 minutes and 49 seconds to win the competition.

As you can imagine, there was a lot of travel involved, not to mention the time it took to set up the city and all the hotels and restaurants in the area. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Home Made Mince Pie is a 1910 American silent short comedy produced by the Thanhouser Company. The film is a comedy of circumstances, in which
reference_text: the Gale family is going to host a dinner. The focus of the humor is in a mince pie that brandy is added to in an attempt to make it more appreciable, but three people each add brandy to the pie. Everyone becomes tipsy upon eating the pie, including the family cat, and the film concludes. No cast or staff credits for this film are known. The film was released on September 27, 1910, to mixed reviews in trade publications. Reviewers mentioned that the film was too long and it was unbelievable that one pie split eight ways would be able to impact everyone. The film is presumed lost.

Plot [ edit ]

An old man comes home to find his wife having a dream about a horse. The old man is worried that something is wrong, but his wife reassures him that it is just a dream. In the dream, the horse is riding across the room and knocking over a vase filled with marzipan. The old man takes the marzipan and puts it in the pie dish, which looks like a mince pie. After some deliberation, he decides to call the police for help. They arrive and ask what he is doing with the marzipan. The old man tells them that he is making a mince pie out of it. The police, having no idea what to do, do not take the pie seriously at first, but as time goes on, they begin to get the hang of it. At the end of the film, the pie is made and everyone is happy.

Scarlett and Atticus fall in love, but it is not long before jealousy and jealousy's corollary, infidelity, ensue. At the end of the film, the love triangle is resolved, and Scarlett marries Atticus. Plot Synopsis Edit

In the summer of 1941, a group of Japanese-American World War II veterans are on a picnic in San Francisco's Golden Gate Park when they are accosted by a man dressed in a kimono. The man introduces himself as Hiram Bingham, one of the most notorious gangsters in the East Coast crime syndicate that operated out of New York City. After some back and forth, Bingham demands that the veterans hand over their valuables, which they do without a murmur. In the middle of the exchange, an American flag flies at half-mast to honor the war dead. As the veterans look on in bewilderment, Bingham pulls out a.45-caliber pistol and shoots one of them in the back of the head. The other two fall to the ground, dead.

Bingham, his henchmen, and two bodyguards rush to the veterans' camp, where they have set up a safe house. One of the bodyguards is the son of a high-ranking Japanese-American official in the United States government, and the other is a veteran with a grudge against Bingham. The three begin to interrogate the veterans, asking them about their family and what they did during the war. However, none of the veterans have any information to give, and

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The The Moving Picture World reviewer found the subject to be too long, but did not find it to be a fault. The reviewer states, " A domestic
reference_text: comedy with a different flavor. In fact, with a mince pie for a basis the flavor comes to resemble brandy very strongly by the time that the cook, the maid and the mistress of the house and her daughter have added the proper proportion of flavoring, neither one knowing that the others have done likewise. The humor in this piece centers around this pie. What happened to the guests who partook of it certainly draws upon the imagination. Imagine eight people, not to speak of the cat, getting drunk on the brandy in one mince pie!... We do not single out this subject as being more evidently padded than others shown on the screen this week. Licensed as well as Independents were guilty and it is time that the manufacturers realize the importance of the scenario end of matters. The mince pie episode was well done, which is the faint praise that we do not like to mete out to anyone. " Walton of The Moving Picture News was not amused by the plot and stated, " To me the last scene had no humor. It was only the necessary ending to the beginning. True humor does not emanate from cognac. " The New York Dramatic Mirror stated, " This is the old story of too many cooks, and it is quite funny after the first scenes are out of the way. The early part of the film takes too much time with trivial details leading up to the final situation.... A weak point in the story is the fact that the pie is cut into eight small pieces, making it difficult to believe in its remarkable power. Two pies would have been as easy to make as one and would have been more convincing. The character parts are all well taken, although the cook would have been better if she had not seized so many opportunities to talk directly at the camera. "

drama about a man who moves to Los Angeles to be with his long-suffering wife, played by Meryl Streep. This is, of course, the sort of melodrama that Hollywood prides itself on churning out at a prodigious rate, and it doesn't take long for the film to go off the rails. In an effort to create a sense of home, and with little success, the film spends a lot of time on the trappings of the film industry, which is to say not much at all. Innovation & Inspiration

As a designer, one of the most important things to me is to be inspired by the world around me. This is an art that I learned from my father, who was a sculptor and art restorer. His love for art led him to create a museum in his back yard where he would spend hours every day in the early 1900's sculpting and restoring works of art. It was this passion that inspired me to take art and design classes at the University of California, Berkeley while I was in high school. From there, I studied graphic design at San Francisco State University and worked as a copywriter for a design/publishing company for six years. After graduating, I decided to pursue my dream of becoming a full-time designer and started freelancing in New York City. During this time, I had the opportunity to work with some of the most creative people in the world, such as Paul Rand, Andy Warhol, Diane Arbus, Cindy Sherman, Robert Rauschenberg, David Chipperfield, Frank Gehry, Richard Serra, John Baldessari, Jean-Mic

The number of people claiming unemployment benefit in the UK has fallen by 1.3 million in the past year, official figures show.

The number of people claiming JSA fell by 730,000 to a record low of 1.9 million in the three months to the end of September.

Horrible Bosses is a point and click adventure game about a boss who wants to rule the world. You play as the titular boss, and every time you get a new power, you have to choose which one to use. For example, in the first level, you get telekinesis, which lets you move objects around without touching them. Later on, you get mind control, which lets you take control of other people's minds. This is great for interrogating them, but not so great for using them as cannon fodder. The game keeps you on your toes, and makes you think about what you're going to do next. If you're a masochist, you can do all the things in the game, but be prepared for a game over at the end.

In August 2013, it was announced that Gordon would not be returning to direct because of scheduling conflicts and that the studio was actively searching for a replacement. In September 2013, Sean Anders was announced as Gordon's replacement, with John Morris joining the production as a producer. The pair had previously performed a rewrite on Goldstein's and Daley's sequel script. Filming had been scheduled to begin in summer 2013, but began in November 2013. Foxx, Jennifer Aniston, and Kevin Spacey reprised their roles, with Christoph Waltz and Chris Pine joining the cast.

Plot Synopsis Edit

Seth Gordon is a high school dropout who finds himself in a life-changing situation when he falls in love with the love of his life, Rachel McAdams. With the help of his family, they set out to make it work, but it's not easy. After an accident on the ski slopes, Seth has amnesia and wakes up in San Francisco's Haight-Ashbury district, where he runs into Rachel for the first time in twenty years. The two of them form a fast friendship and begin to learn about each other's pasts and what it means to be a grown-up.

During the trial, prosecutors played recordings of conversations between Turner and the informant, whose identity was not revealed for security reasons. One conversation took place in a parking garage at the George Washington University Medical Center in Washington, D.C., where Turner was receiving treatment for back pain.

Turner, dressed in a suit and tie, talked about "going to the White House and blowing up the South Lawn," court documents said.

Biography

Early life

Graves was born in a farmhouse in the village of Wootton Bassett, Wiltshire, England. His father was a carpenter and his mother a seamstress. At the age of six, Graves began to read voraciously, and was a good student in his school. He graduated from High School at the age of sixteen, and went on to study law at Exeter University. During his time at Exeter, Graves met his future wife, the woman who would become his wife for the next twenty-two years. The couple got married in 1891, and moved to New York City to start a family. After a year of living in New York, Graves decided to return to his home village for a few months, and took a job as a labourer on a farm owned by his father-in-law. While working on the farm, Graves fell in love with a farmhand named Mary (née O'Rourke), and asked her to marry him. She said yes, and the two were married that same year. In the years that followed, Graves grew to love Mary with all his heart, and became the breadwinner of the family.

A world without nuclear weapons is the dream of Dr. Emmett Brown, a scientist who believes that his time has come. In order to get the world to move in that direction, he begins a research project called Project Purity, which involves implanting nanobots into the brains of test subjects who have been brainwashed into serving the war effort. One of the subjects is Jack D'Aurora, a high school dropout who dreams of becoming a fighter pilot. D'Aurora is sent to the U.S. Air Force Academy in Colorado as a test subject for Project Purity. Upon arriving at the academy, D'Aurora's training is interrupted by the arrival of an alien known as Icarus, who has crash-landed on the campus. The two engage in a dogfight, and during the course of the battle, Icarus reveals that he is, in fact, a cyborg with the ability to fly through the air at supersonic speeds. Biography Edit

Early life Edit

An Oxford graduate, Ayola grew up in a working-class family in Oxford, the eldest of three children. After studying drama at King's College, Cambridge, he went on to work as a scriptwriter for television and radio, most notably as co-writer of the British version of Monty Python's Flying Circus which was broadcast in the United States and other countries. During this time he developed a love of science fiction and fantasy, and as a result became fascinated with the worlds created by JRR Tolkien, Fritz Leiber and Robert E. Howard. This led him to write his first novel, A Time for Dreaming, in which he set out to explore the mythological underpinnings of Middle-earth. The book was a bestseller and won the Whitbread-Prize for Young Poets and Short Story Writers in 1980.

Personal life

Ayola was born in Bournemouth, Dorset, the daughter of an Anglican vicar and a schoolteacher. She grew up in Southmead, Middlesex, where she studied drama at King's College, Cambridgeshire. Her career began in the mid-1980s, when she auditioned for the Royal Shakespeare Company's Hamlet and was cast as Ophelia in A Midsummer Night's Dream. After a break to pursue a career in television, she returned to the RSC in the summer of 1989 to play Claudius in Julius Caesar, which went on to win the Palme d'Or at Cannes. The following year, she took on the role of Lavinia in Macbeth as well as The Tragedy of King Lear. During the 1990s, she made guest appearances on Doctor Who, Torchwood, Coronation Street, Broadchurch, EastEnders, Black Adder, Strictly Come Dancing, Casualty, Emmerdale, Downton Abbey, Midsomer Murders, Murder in the First, The Billiards Master of Ceremonies, the X-Files, Law & Order: Special Victims Unit, and many others.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Traditional Chinese literary criticism emphasized the life of the author when interpreting a work, a practice which Burton Watson attributes to " the close links that traditional Chinese thought pos
reference_text: its between art and morality ". Since many of Du Fu's poems feature morality and history, this practice is particularly important. Another reason, identified by the Chinese historian William Hung, is that Chinese poems are typically concise, omitting context that might be relevant, but which an informed contemporary could be assumed to know. For modern Western readers, " The less accurately we know the time, the place and the circumstances in the background, the more liable we are to imagine it incorrectly, and the result will be that we either misunderstand the poem or fail to understand it altogether ". Stephen Owen suggests a third factor particular to Du Fu, arguing that the variety of the poet's work required consideration of his whole life, rather than the " reductive " categorizations used for more limited poets.

Origins [ edit ]

[2] According to legend, the story of the An Lushan Rebellion is a retold tale of Qin Shi Huang's ( 土宗皇 ) son, Zhuge Liang ( 張龙 ) who rebelled against his father to gain the throne of Qin Shihuang ( 平水明 ). Zhuge Liang was an illegitimate son of Qin Shi Huang, and his birth was marred by a failed marriage at the age of six. After this, Zhuge Liang grew up resentful of his father's favoritism, and began to take matters into his own hands. This led to his father's death in 751, and the usurpation of the throne by his half-brother, Li Jue ( 黃雲 ). Zhuge Liang fled to the court of the Tang emperors, hoping to become a concubine in the future. Chang 'an's death was mourned by the court, and there was a period of mourning for seven years. During this time, no one was allowed to wear the crown of the Emperors of the Tang dynasty without the permission of the Grand Concubine Dowager. It was the custom for the crown to be passed from father to son, and this had been done in the case of Chang 'an. After the coronation of his son, the crown was passed to his grand-daughter, who was given the title of 'Empress Dowager'.


At the end of the seven years of mourning, on the death of the Emperor Huanzong in 758, the Empress Dowager had an audience with the newly-crowned Emperor Xianzong, and asked him to make a marriage proposal to her. He refused, and her anger was inflamed. She went to the palace, and said that she would be content with nothing less than the throne of the Imperial State. Born in 551 BCE, Lu Xun was the son of a merchant and had a prosperous career as a statesman. At the age of twenty-year-old, he took the throne of Lu by overthrowing his father and ruling for three years. The year 604 was a turning point in his life, as he began to focus on the problems of the common people and set about reformulating the government from the ground up.

In the next twenty years, Lu made a name for himself as a reformer, instituting a tax system that paid taxes to the landowning class and redistributing land to the poor. He also abolished the death penalty for crimes, made marriage between first cousins a legal form of consanguinity, and allowed women to inherit property without dowry. All of these reforms were in line with the teachings of Confucius, who believed that there was no need for government to be involved in the day-to-day affairs of the people.

As a reward for his victory, he offered to marry Huizong's daughter, which he did.

The Battle of Wuzhang had the effect of uniting the people of the north-eastern part of the Yangtze delta in a common cause against the central government. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Du Fu's work is notable above all for its range. Chinese critics traditionally used the term 集大成 ( jídàch
reference_text: éng- " complete symphony " ), a reference to Mencius'description of Confucius. Yuan Zhen was the first to note the breadth of Du Fu's achievement, writing in 813 that his predecessor, " united in his work traits which previous men had displayed only singly ". He mastered all the forms of Chinese poetry : Chou says that in every form he " either made outstanding advances or contributed outstanding examples ". Furthermore, his poems use a wide range of registers, from the direct and colloquial to the allusive and self @-@ consciously literary. This variety is manifested even within individual works : Owen identifies the, " rapid stylistic and thematic shifts " in poems which enable the poet to represent different facets of a situation, while Chou uses the term " juxtaposition " as the major analytical tool in her work. Du Fu is noted for having written more on poetics and painting than any other writer of his time. He wrote eighteen poems on painting alone, more than any other Tang poet. Du Fu's seemingly negative commentary on the prized horse paintings of Han Gan ignited a controversy that has persisted to the present day.

Born in 1894, Du Fu was the son of a well-regarded poet and his wife. At the age of twenty-one, he began to write for the public, and by the time he was thirty-three, he had published over one hundred poems and more than a hundred short stories. These works range from satirical riffs on social mores to lyrical meditations on the life of the individual. Some of his most famous works are A Poem of Spring (1904), in which he imagines a man-eating tiger that roams the streets of Chang'an, to the novella I Dreamed of a White Horse (1906), in which a group of peasants attempt to make a horse by grafting a human head onto a horse's body.

As a poet, Du Fu is best known for his work in the vernacular, a style that emerged in the 1920s and '30s as a counterpoint to the literati-influenced poetry of the Tang dynasty. This was a time of social upheavals, and poetry was one of the few ways of expressing the pain and suffering of the

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> It was in the 11th century, during the Northern Song era that Du Fu's reputation reached its peak. In this period a comprehensive re @-
reference_text: @ evaluation of earlier poets took place, in which Wang Wei, Li Bai and Du Fu came to be regarded as representing respectively the Buddhist, Daoist and Confucian strands of Chinese culture. At the same time, the development of Neo @-@ Confucianism ensured that Du Fu, as its poetic exemplar, occupied the paramount position. Su Shi famously expressed this reasoning when he wrote that Du Fu was " preeminent... because... through all his vicissitudes, he never for the space of a meal forgot his sovereign ". His influence was helped by his ability to reconcile apparent opposites : political conservatives were attracted by his loyalty to the established order, while political radicals embraced his concern for the poor. Literary conservatives could look to his technical mastery, while literary radicals were inspired by his innovations. Since the establishment of the People's Republic of China, Du Fu's loyalty to the state and concern for the poor have been interpreted as embryonic nationalism and socialism, and he has been praised for his use of simple, " people's language ".

Huangdi was well versed in the teachings of his forefathers and knew how to make use of the material at his disposal. After several years of study, he came to the conclusion that there was no need to rely on the text of the Huainanzi as a source of knowledge, but was in fact able to draw on a wide range of sources, including the work of the scholars of the Han dynasty, such as Lu Xun 董玉, Zhang Liao 东文, and Li Hui 朱海. This was the beginning of the period of "scholarship" known as the "Three Dynasties" (Jingzong 古代, Zhongguo 南都, Shandong 四川).

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Until the 13th century, the Japanese preferred Bai Juyi above all poets and there were few references to Du Fu, although his influence can be seen
reference_text: in some kanshi ( " Chinese poetry made by Japanese poets " ) anthologies such as Bunka Shūreishū in the 9th century. The first notable Japanese appreciator of Du Fu's poetry was Kokan Shiren ( 1278 – 1346 ), a Rinzai Zen patriarch and one of the most prominent authors of the literature of the Five Mountains ; he highly praised Du Fu and made a commentary on some poems of Du Fu from the perspective of a Zen priest in Vol. 11 of Saihokushū. His student Chūgan Engetsu composed many kanshi which were clearly stated " influenced by Du Fu " in their prefaces. Chūgan's student Gidō Shūshin had close connection with the Court and Ashikaga Shogunate and propagated Du Fu's poetry in the mundane world ; one day Nijō Yoshimoto, the Kampaku regent of the Court and the highest authority of renga poetry, asked Gidō, " Should I learn the poetry of Du Fu and Li Bai? " Gidō dared to reply, " Yes if you do have enough capability. No if do not. " Since then, there had been many seminars on Du Fu's poetry both in Zen temples and in the aristocratic society, and as a result his poetry was often cited in Japanese literature in the Muromachi period, e.g., Taiheiki, a historical epic in the late 14th century, and some noh plays such as Hyakuman, Bashō, and Shunkan.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> A variety of styles have been used in efforts to translate Du Fu's work into English. As Burton Watson remarks in The Selected Poems of Du Fu
reference_text: , " There are many different ways to approach the problems involved in translating Du Fu, which is why we need as many different translations as possible " ( p. xxii ). The translators have had to contend with bringing out the formal constraints of the original without sounding laboured to a Western ear ( particularly when translating regulated verse, or lǜshi ), and accommodating the complex allusions contained particularly in the later works ( Hawkes writes that " his poems do not as a rule come through very well in translation " — p. ix ). One extreme on each issue is represented by Kenneth Rexroth's One Hundred Poems From the Chinese. His are free translations, which seek to conceal the parallelisms through enjambement and expansion and contraction of the content ; his responses to the allusions are firstly to omit most of these poems from his selection, and secondly to " translate out " the references in those works which he does select.

This is in keeping with the style of the poem, which is characterized by rhyme and concordance of line and stanza.

One of the most popular translations is the so-called Pinyin transliteration, which uses the phonetic values of the Chinese characters to represent the English syllables. This has been the source of much controversy, as well as a great deal of confusion among readers. For example, the translator has been accused of plagiarizing an earlier translation of the poem, and in recent years it has been pointed out that the Pinyin transliteration is not a translation at all, but a paraphrase of the original. A good example of this can be found in the introduction to John Keats's 1819 edition of Paradise Lost, which begins with the following sentence: "To this poem is due the invention of the Pinyin transliteration, which has proved to be a faithful, though by no means infallible, translation." Kiss You received mixed reviews from critics, but was a commercial success, peaking at number two on the U.K. Singles Chart and selling over 100,000 copies in the U.S. In an interview with Mojo, Waters claimed that this success was due to the band's "lucrative deal with Elektra Records, which paid the band a royalty every time a record was played on the radio and in cinemas." The following year, The Wall Street Journal published an article in which it was revealed that Elektra had in fact agreed to pay the band $1.5 million for the rights to "Kiss You" and its follow-up, Another Brick in the Wall, which were released in March and April of 1970. As a result of this deal, both albums went on to sell over a million copies (Aldous Huxley's Brave New World: Or, the Technological Society and Its Future, for example, sold over 2.5 million copies in hardcover and more than 1.5 million copies in paperback).

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Despite the expensive reconstructions, both vessels were considered obsolete by the eve of the Pacific War, and neither saw significant action in the early years of the war
reference_text: . Following the loss of most of the IJN's large aircraft carriers during the Battle of Midway in mid @-@ 1942, they were rebuilt with a flight deck replacing the rear pair of gun turrets to give them the ability to operate an air group of floatplanes. A lack of aircraft and qualified pilots, however, meant that they never actually operated their aircraft in combat. While awaiting their air group the sister ships were sometimes used to ferry troops and material to Japanese bases. They participated in the Battle of Cape Engaño in late 1944, where they decoyed the American carrier fleet supporting the invasion of Leyte away from the landing beaches. Afterwards both ships were transferred to Southeast Asia ; in early 1945 they participated in Operation Kita, where they transported petrol and other strategic materials to Japan. The sisters were then reduced to reserve until they were sunk during American airstrikes in July. After the war they were scrapped in 1946 – 47.

As well as being larger, the new ship would weigh twice as much as the Constitution, and its deck plating would be three times as thick. This extra weight would be offset by the reduction in space taken up by the gun turrets, which would be moved to the bow of the ship, making it easier to fire while at the same time less obtrusive to the waterline.

Rutledge's design won the contract, and construction began in 1855. On June 1, 1856, the USS Constitution was launched at Bath Iron Works in Maine, and began sea trials the following month. After a year of testing, the ship was christened "Constitution" for the first time on July 4, 1857, just two months after the Civil War ended. In the years that followed, the Constitution proved to be a tough ship to beat, and her reputation grew to the point where she was referred to as "the King of Battleships."

Photo: Imperial War Museum Aircrew manning the Mk.V-1 radar in the bow of the Fairey Swordfish. This radar was a development of the V-2, which could detect targets at up to 100 miles (160 km) away. The aircraft carried a range of radar homing torpedoes, anti-ship missiles and depth charges. These were launched from the starboard side of the ship, and their speed was dependent on the angle of attack they were launched at. When the torpedo hit the target, it detonated on impact, blowing a hole in the target to a depth of 1,000 feet (305 m). The target was then "tagged" by the radar, and the range to the target was calculated. This was used to guide the torpedo detonation in the area of the target. It was hoped that this would result in a hit on the target, and if not, the ship would return to home base for refuelling. However, there were problems with the radar, such as interference from sea state changes, which led to it being phased out of service in the 1960s. A more modern version of the radar, the Mk.V-2, was used on the Harrier GR.

Espiritu Santo lost his ship, but the Chesapeake escaped unscathed. On December 18, the United States entered the war by declaring war on Great Britain. Two days later, President James Madison signed the Declaration of War, which gave the United States the right to "repel any Invasion" of the North American continent. In the years that followed, the War of 1812 would become the bloodiest conflict in American history, resulting in the deaths of more than 5,000 Americans and at least as many British and Native American soldiers.

By the time the war ended in 1815, there were few Americans left who remembered the Napoleonic Wars. Most of the country had grown up in the 19th century, and only a few had been exposed to the horrors of war. As a result, it was easy for Americans to look askance at the British and feel justified in doing whatever was necessary to win the war. This was especially true in the South, where anti-British sentiment was at its highest. Even those Northerners who had fought in the Civil War were reluctant to get involved in another war without a clear end in sight.

Hurricane and tropical storm intensities are influenced by sea surface temperatures (SSTs), which are in turn influenced by topography (elevation and slope). The relationship between SSTs and wind speeds is well known, but there is no consensus on the influence of land surface temperature (LSST) on hurricane intensity. This study attempts to fill this gap by quantifying the relationship between LSST and hurricane intensity using a data set of over 1,000 tropical cyclones since 1851. Our results show that, on average, a 1° × 1° grid cell with an average SST of 30°C (86°F) has a hurricane intensity of 0.05 (95% confidence interval [CI] = 0.01–0.08) m/s −1, which is similar to the value of 0.05 m/s −1 obtained by other studies. This result is consistent with the hypothesis that hurricanes are stronger in warmer than cooler regions of the tropics. However, we are unable to rule out the possibility that the strength of hurricanes is related to the amount of moisture in the atmosphere, which is a function of air temperature. A century later, there are signs of the storm's impact all around South Florida. In Broward County, for example, about half of the area's tree canopy was destroyed, according to U.S. Forest Service data. That's an area the size of New Jersey.

It's unclear how much of the damage was man-made, but scientists are trying to figure that out. One theory is that climate change is playing a role. Rising temperatures and sea levels have led to more rain and storm surges, which in turn make it harder for trees to take root.

"The problem is that we're going to have a lot more water in the future," said Kevin Trenberth, a climate scientist at the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colo. "That's going to increase the frequency and intensity of storms."

Trenberth's research has found that tropical cyclones are intensifying in the Atlantic and Pacific oceans, and that those storms are more likely to hit densely populated areas. A study published in the journal Nature Climate Change last year found that Florida's population has grown three times faster than the state's land area since 1950.

This area was the site of the Battle of Pork Chop Hill, a key battle in the Korean War that took place on April 25, 1950. Pork Chop Hill was an impregnable hilltop with a commanding view of the city of Seoul. The United States Air Force (USAF) decided to use the hill as a staging area for air strikes against North Korea. In the early morning hours of April 25, 50 B-29 Superfortresses took off from Tinian Island in the Marianas archipelago and headed for the top of Pork Chop Hill. Their mission was to drop napalm and strafe artillery positions, while the ground troops supported by tank destroyers and fighter escorts provided fire support. At 10:00 a.m., the first bomb was dropped on the north side of the hill, followed by a second later that day. By the end of the day, over 1,000 tons of napalm had been dropped on the hill. It was, of course, a prelude to the Battle of the Somme, which took place on the same day and in the same battle-scarred, craggy hills of Flanders. But the First World War was no ordinary war. At its heart was a conflict between two fundamentally different worldviews, the world of Napoleon and the world of Clausewitz. Both were inextricably linked to the events of 1812-1815, but they had divergent fates. Napoleon's dream of a grandiose empire was to culminate in the Napoleonic Wars, while Clausewitz's world was to be dominated by Prussia and the Austro-Hungarian Empire.

Clausewitz's influence was felt in every aspect of the war, from the battlefield to the armaments industry. As well as laying the foundations for modern strategists, he was the first to see that war was a never-ending process of manoeuvring, counter-mouthing and recriminations. NEW YORK (MarketWatch) — There's a story you hear a lot about the Battle of Midway, the Pacific-to-Korean landings in World War II. It's that the Japanese were able to outgun the Americans by using wooden ships, which they loaded with torpedoes and machine guns.

This may be true, but it's not the whole story. In fact, the battle was a stalemate, at least for the first half of the battle. As long as the Americans had a lot of firepower, they were able to inflict damage on the Japanese ships without losing too many ships to torpedo attacks.

That's no longer the case. New technology has made it possible for the U.S. Navy to shoot down enemy ships with cruise missiles, and it's doing so more and more these days.

Here's a look at how things have changed over the past 50 years.

1941: World War II in the Pacific

Japan's attack on Pearl Harbor set off a chain of events that led to the end of World War II in the Pacific. On Dec. 7, 1941, the Japanese began an amphibious invasion of the Philippines, followed by a push into Malaya and Indochina.

The CSS Manassas was a 5,000-ton sloop-of-war built in 1854 by the U.S. Navy for the East India Company. At the time, the company was in the process of expanding its fleet to meet the demands of the opium trade, which was booming in China. By the 1850s, the Chinese had become the world's largest opium cultivators, and a steady stream of opium was shipped to New York, London, and other ports on the Atlantic seaboard. This demand was met by shipwrights and ironmongers in the Chesapeake and Potomac basins, who worked feverishly to build ships that could carry tons of opium without breaking the bank. One of the most ambitious projects was the construction of the CSS Manassas, which was intended to be the largest warship in the world. Construction began in 1855, and the ship was christened on 1 April 1856. After a year of testing, the ship was launched on 15 May 1857, and began her sea trials the following month. In the summer of 1858, the Navy signed a contract for her construction, and the ship was ready for sea in the fall of that year.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The weakness of the breech @-@ loader was the obvious problem of sealing the breech. All guns are powered by the explosive conversion of gunpowder
reference_text: into gas. This explosion propels the shot or shell out of the front of the gun, but also imposes great stresses on the gun @-@ barrel. If the breech — which experiences some of the greatest forces in the gun — is not entirely secure, then there is a risk that either gas will discharge through the breech or that the breech will break. This in turn reduces the muzzle velocity of the weapon and can also endanger the gun crew. The Warrior's Armstrong guns suffered from both problems ; the shells were unable to penetrate the 4 @.@ 5 in ( 118 mm ) armor of Gloire, while sometimes the screw which closed the breech flew backwards out of the gun on firing. Similar problems were experienced with the breech @-@ loading guns which became standard in the French and German navies.

In order to fire a.30 caliber machine gun, the propellant has to be compressed to less than one-tenth of its original volume. This is accomplished by compressing the air-to-powder mixture, which is in turn compressed by the recoil of the gun.

There are two types of compression: cyclic and reciprocating. Reciprocating compression is the most common, and has been used since the invention of the muzzle-loading musket in the 1600s. As the name implies, it consists of a piston moving back and forth in a cylinder. The piston is held in place by a cams, which are pivoted at the end of the cylinder. When the piston is at rest, the cams are free to oscillate, but when the piston is moving forward, the cams are locked against rotation. This type of compression is referred to as cyclic (see Figure 1).

Figure 1. Illustration of a cyclic-compression system.

As an ideal, the model army did not have a military hierarchy, but each soldier was expected to take care of his own well-being and those of his fellow soldiers. This was in contrast to the military hierarchy that existed in Eliot's day, where the higher-ranking soldiers were expected to look out for the welfare of the lower-ranking soldiers.

In 1884, Eliot began writing The Waste Land, a novel about a war between man and nature. The novel received mixed reviews, but was well-received by critics for its depiction of the struggle between man and nature. After its publication, Eliot went on to write other novels, including Poems and Prose (1891), Middlemarch (1897), and Wuthering Heights (1898). His poetry has been translated into more than a dozen languages.

What is the difference between a fairy tale and a holocaust story?

There are a number of differences. First, they are different in subject matter. The Holocaust is a horror story, which means that it deals with the death of human beings—in this case, Jews—and not with the story of a man who falls in love with a mermaid. Also, the Holocaust is an atrocity, which means that it takes place in a place where human beings are at risk of being killed. For example, the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising of 1944-45 was an atrocity, as was the bombing of Dresden in 1945. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Temnospondyli ( from Greek τέμνειν ( temnein, " to cut " ) and σπ
reference_text: όνδυλος ( spondylos, " vertebra " ) ) is a diverse subclass of extinct small to giant tetrapods — often considered primitive amphibians — that flourished worldwide during the Carboniferous, Permian, and Triassic periods. A few species continued into the Cretaceous. Fossils have been found on every continent. During about 210 million years of evolutionary history, they adapted to a wide range of habitats, including fresh water, terrestrial, and even coastal marine environments. Their life history is well understood, with fossils known from the larval stage, metamorphosis, and maturity. Most temnospondyls were semiaquatic, although some were almost fully terrestrial, returning to the water only to breed. These temnospondyls were some of the first vertebrates fully adapted to life on land. Although temnospondyls are considered amphibians, many had characteristics, such as scales, claws, and armour @-@ like bony plates, that distinguish them from modern amphibians.

ῆλη ( spondyli, " horn " ) ) are a group of soft bodied vertebrates. They are characterized by a bony ridge on the ventral surface of the caudal vertebrae, which is thought to play a role in locomotion. There are three genera of Temnospondyli: Aplysia, Anomalocaris, and Pachyrhynchus.

Distribution [ edit ]

Tammarskia, an extinct species of Temnospondyli.

Inhabitants [ edit ]

Carnivorous and omnivorous, Temnospondyli are found in temperate and tropical regions of the world. Their habitat ranges from subtropical rainforests to arid savannas, and can be found in a variety of habitats, including river deltas, swamps, mangrove swamps, estuaries, marshes, bogs, saltmarshes, and freshwater lakes. Some species have been found in areas that are unsuitable for human habitation, such as the Everglades of Florida, as well as at elevations of 2000 m (6500 ft) or higher.

Behavior [ edit ]

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Many temnospondyls are much larger than living amphibians, and superficially resemble crocodiles. Others are smaller and resemble salamanders
reference_text: . Most have broad, flat heads that are either blunt ( brevirostrine ) or elongated ( longirostrine ). The skulls are rounded or triangular in shape when viewed from above, and are usually covered in pits and ridges. The rugged surfaces of bones may have supported blood vessels, which could transfer carbon dioxide to the bones to neutralize acidic build up in the blood ( early semiaquatic tetrapods would have had difficulty expelling carbon dioxide from their bodies while on land, and these dermal bones may have been an early solution to the problem ). Many temnospondyls also have canal @-@ like grooves in their skulls called sensory sulci. The sulci, which usually run around the nostrils and eye sockets, are part of a lateral line system used to detect vibrations in water. As semiaquatic animals, most temnospondyls have small limbs with four toes on each front foot and five on each hind foot. Terrestrial temnospondyls have larger, thicker limbs, and some even have claws. One unusual terrestrial temnospondyl, Fayella, has relatively long limbs for its body, and probably lived as an active runner able to chase prey.

TEMNOSPHONDYL SKELETAL FEATURES The vertebrae of this group are elongate, tapering from the end of the snout to the base of the tail. The head is broad and flat, with a rounded snout and large eyes. The nostrils are close together and protrude from the sides of the head. The skin is dark brown to black in color, wrinkled, and scaly. The scales are long and thin, ranging from 1/4 to 1/2 inch in length. There are two to five spines on the back and one or two on the flanks. The forelimbs are similar to those of lizards, but the front limbs are longer and more slender. The hind limbs are short and stubby. The tail is long and slender, reaching a maximum length of about 15 inches.

reference_text: the skull, such as interfrontals, internasals, and interparietals, that have developed in some temnospondyl taxa. Most temnospondyls have tabular horns in the backs of their skulls, rounded projections of bone separated from the rest of the skull by indentations called otic notches ; in some temnospondyls, such as Zatrachys, they are pointed and very prominent. Among the most distinguishing features of temnospondyls are the interpterygoid vacuities, two large holes in the back of the palate. Another pair of holes, choanae, are present in front of these vacuities, and connect the nasal passage with the mouth. Temnospondyls often have teeth on their palates, as well as in their jaws. Some of these teeth are so large, they are referred to as tusks. In some temnospondyls, such as Nigerpeton, tusks in the lower jaw pierce the palate and emerge through openings in the top of the skull.

Credit: University of California, Merced A new study shows that an amphibian known as the horse gecko (Theraphosa leucogenys) can learn to avoid predation by mimicking the behavior of its reptilian predator, the salamander.

The researchers, led by U.C. Merced paleontologist Robert Reisz, published their findings in the open-access journal PLOS ONE.

Horse geckos are well known for their ability to climb trees and burrow into crevices, but it's not clear how they do it. Some scientists have suggested that the geckos use suction cups to pull themselves up the trunks of trees, but this has not been conclusively proven.

In the new study, Reisz and his colleagues set out to find out how the geckos manage to climb trees without relying on suction cups. Using X-ray computed tomography (CT) scans, the researchers were able to measure the thickness of the gecko's skin and how much pressure it exerts on the tree trunk. This information was used to create a 3D model of the gecko's body, which was then used to simulate how the gecko would climb a tree.

Ternospondyls have an even more complex arrangement of spines, but they are arranged in a way that does not encircle the spinal cord. Instead, the spines are arranged radially from the centrum to the end of the axial skeleton. This arrangement results in a relatively flat, cylindrical body rather than a spindly, conical one. There are two types of ternospondyls: long-snouted and short-snouted.

Lengthening of the spine is the most obvious difference between the two types of ternospondyls. Long-snouted ternospondyls have a long, tubular spine that tapers to a point at the end of the thoracic segment. The length of the spine is proportional to the length of the body, so a long-snouted ternospondyl is proportionally longer than a short-snouted one.

reference_text: number of separate elements, were placed in the suborder Rachitomi, and large Triassic aquatic forms with simpler vertebrae were placed in the suborder Stereospondyli. With the recent growth of phylogenetics, this classification is no longer viable. The basic rhachitomous condition is found in many primitive tetrapods, and is not unique to one group of temnospondyls. Some temnospondyls have rhachitomous, semirhachitomous, and sterospondylous vertebrae at different points in the same vertebral column. Other taxa have intermediate morphologies that do not fit into any category. Rachitomi is no longer recognized as a group, but Stereospondyli is still considered valid. Nematostomata are a monophyletic group of invertebrates that includes echinoderms, cnidarians, annelids, arthropods, and mollusks (reviewed in DePristo et al. 2006 ). In addition to the well-accepted phylogeographic relationships among these groups, recent studies have begun to elucidate the evolution of the group and its relationships within the animal kingdom. One of the most controversial issues is the classification of the group as a monophyletic group or, alternatively, as a paraphyletic group consisting of at least two or more subfamilies (Gardiner 1983 ; O'Shea and Horsbakken 2005 ). This dichotomy has been a source of controversy for more than a century, and continues to be an enigma to many paleontologists in the 21st century.

Edopoids include the Late Carboniferous genus Edops and the family Cochleosauridae. Dendrerpetontidae has also been included in Edopoidea, and is the oldest known temnospondyl family. Balanerpeton woodi is the oldest species, having been present over 330 million years ago during the Viséan stage of the Early Carboniferous. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> In 2000, paleontologists Adam Yates and Anne Warren produced a revised phylogeny of more derived temnospondyls, naming several new clades
reference_text: . Two major clades were Euskelia and Limnarchia. Euskelia includes the temnospondyls that were once called rhachitomes and includes two subfamilies, the Dissorophoidea and the Eryopoidea. Dissorophoids include small, mostly terrestrial temnospondyls that may be the ancestors of modern amphibians. Eryopoids include larger temnospondyls like Eryops. The second major clade, Limnarchia, includes most Mesozoic temnospondyls, as well as some Permian groups. Within Limnarchia are the superfamily Archegosauroidea and the most derived temnospondyls, the stereospondyls.

Phylogeny is the study of relationships among organisms, and it is essential for reconstructing evolutionary history. One of the most important aspects of phylogeny is the placement of genera within a group. This placement is known as monophyly, and there are at least three commonly accepted methods for determining monophyly: parsimony, maximum likelihood, and Bayesian clustering. All three methods have their pros and cons, and each method has its own strengths and weaknesses. Parsimony is the most common method, and it is used to determine the most parsimonious tree (e.g., the one with the fewest number of steps). Maximum likelihood is a much more powerful method, but it requires large sample sizes and the ability to deal with outliers. Bayesian clustering is similar to maximum likelihood, but it uses information from a prior distribution to assign taxa to groups. The problem with these methods is that they are computationally expensive, and many species are missing from the data set. As a result, it is not possible to make inferences about the relationships

Trematosaurs include a diversity of temnospondyls, including large marine trematosauroids, aquatic plagiosaurs, brachyopoids that survived into the Cretaceous, and metoposauroids with eyes near the front of their heads. In 2000, paleontologists Rainer Schoch and Andrew Milner named a third major clade of stereospondyls, the Rhytidostea. This group included more primitive stereospondyls that could not be placed in either Capitosauria or Trematosauria, and included groups like Lydekkerinidae, Rhytidosteidae, and Brachyopoidea. While Capitosauria and Trematosauria are still widely used, Rhytidostea is not often supported as a true clade in recent analyses. Rhytidosteids and brachyopoids are now grouped with trematosaurians, but lydekkerinids are still considered to be a primitive family of stereospondyls.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Recently, the theory that temnospondyls were the ancestors of all lissamphibians has gained wide support. The skull morphology of some
reference_text: small temnospondyls has been compared to those of modern frogs and salamanders, but the presence of bicuspid, pedicellate teeth in small, paedomorphic or immature temnospondyls has been cited as the most convincing argument in favor of the temnospondyl origin of lissamphibians. Seen in lissamphibians and many dissorophoid temnospondyls, pedicellate teeth have calcified tips and bases. During the development of most tetrapods, teeth begin to calcify at their tips. Calcification normally proceeds downward to the base of the tooth, but calcification from the tip stops abruptly in pedicellate teeth. Calcification resumes at the base, leaving an area in the center of the tooth uncalcified. This pattern is seen in living amphibians and fossils.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Most aquatic stereospondyls have flattened heads. When feeding, they probably opened their mouths by lifting their skulls instead of lowering their lower jaws. The
reference_text: jaw mechanics of the plagiosaurid Gerrothorax is well known, and is one of the most highly adapted. Gerrothorax is thought to have lifted its skull to around 50 ° above horizontal through the flexing of the atlanto @-@ occipital joint between the occipital condyles of the skull and the atlas vertebra of the neck. As the skull is raised, the quadrate bone pushes forward and causes the lower jaw to protrude outward. Other stereospondyls probably also lifted their skulls, but they are not as well adapted for such movement. D.M.S. Watson was the first to suggest skull lifting as a means of feeding in temnospondyls. He envisioned that Mastodonsaurus, a much larger temnospondyl than Gerrothorax, was able to make the same movement. Paleontologist A.L. Panchen also supported the idea in 1959, suggesting that Batrachosuchus also fed in this way. At the time it was thought that these temnospondyls lifted their heads with strong jaw muscles, but it is now thought that they used larger muscles in the neck that were attached to the large pectoral girdle. Plagiosuchus, a close relative of Gerrothorax, also has a hyobranchial skeleton that muscles may have attached to. Plagiosuchus has very small teeth and a large area for muscle attachment behind the skull, suggesting that it could suction feed by rapidly opening its mouth.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Temnospondyls, like all amphibians, reproduced in aquatic environments. Most temnospondyls probably reproduced through external fertilization.
reference_text: Like most living frogs, female temnospondyls would have laid masses of eggs in water while males released sperm to fertilize them. Several fossils were described from the Early Permian of Texas in 1998 that may be egg masses of dissorophoid temnospondyls. They were the first known fossils of amphibian eggs. The fossils consist of small disks with thin membranes that are probably vitelline membranes and halo @-@ like areas surrounding them that are most likely mucous coatings. They are attached to plant fossils, suggesting that these temnospondyls laid eggs on aquatic plants much like modern frogs. The mucous membranes show that the eggs were laid by amphibians, not fish ( their eggs lack mucous ), but the type of amphibian that laid them cannot be known because no body fossils are preserved with the eggs. The eggs are thought to be from dissorophoids because they are likely to be close relatives of modern amphibians, and probably had similar reproductive strategies. They are also the most common amphibians from the deposit in which the eggs were found.

Tendency to Reproduce in Limp Bodies

The most common vertebrate in the Triassic–Jurassic biosphere was the sauropod Triceratops horridus, which reached a length of 30 m (see Figure 1). This animal had a body shape that was intermediate between that of crocodiles and lizards, and in some respects was similar to today's pythons. However, there were no reports of T. horridus reproducing outside its watery environment. The reason for this is not known, but may have been related to the fact that T. horridus was one of the few carnivorous dinosaurs that did not have venom glands.

Sauropods, on the other hand, were known to lay eggs in water, and it is possible that some of these eggs were fertilized by sperm from other sauropods. In any case, the oviparous (egg-laying) habit of sauropods has been shown to be a characteristic of this group as a whole. For example, the holotype of Diplodocus sp. (Discovery and description of

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Temnospondyls like Sclerocephalus are known from both large adult specimens and small larvae, showing an extreme change in body shape.
reference_text: In these species, the shape and proportions of skull bones change in the early stages of development. The ornamentation on the surface of the skull roof also develops at this time. Small, regularly spaced pits are the first to form, followed by larger ridges. As development continues, the external gills disappear. Small teeth that once covered the palate are lost. The postcranial skeleton does not develop at the same rate as the skull, with ossification ( the replacement of cartilage by bone ) happening more slowly. Vertebrae and limb bones are poorly developed, ribs and fingers are absent in the early stages, and the scapulocoracoid and ischium are entirely absent through most of development. Once maturity is reached, most bones have fully formed and growth rate slows. The bones of some temnospondyls like Dutuitosaurus show growth marks, possibly an indication that growth rate varied with the change in seasons. Fossils of temnospondyls like Metoposaurus and Cheliderpeton show that individuals grew larger past maturity. The oldest individuals usually have more pitting on their skulls with deeper sulci.

The fossilised remains of the worm, which measures 1.5cm long, were found by a team of palaeontologists from the University of Exeter in collaboration with the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County (NHM) and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).

The discovery is described in the Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society (ZSL) and will be published in a peer-reviewed journal next year.

Temnospondyls are one of the most bizarre invertebrates on the planet, with a mouth filled with spines that protrude from the worm's head. In addition to their mouth, they have an elongated snout, as well as a set of bony protrusions on their head similar to antennae.

These features are thought to help the worm detect prey, and it is thought that they evolved from jawless vertebrates to gain a sense of smell.

However, little is known about the life history of T. exarmigulatus, other than that it inhabits the mudflats of the Gulf of Mexico, feeding on molluscs and crustaceans.

Credit: University of Texas at Austin An international team of paleontologists has discovered a new species of long-necked reptile that lived during the Cretaceous Period (145-66 million years ago), more than 100 million years before the dinosaurs roamed the Earth.
