In addition to the long neck, the researchers found evidence of bony protrusions on the animal's neck, as well as an elongated snout-like snout that may have been used for sniffing out prey.

"What's unique about this animal is that it has all the hallmarks of a sauropod," said Mark Norell, a co-author of the study and curator of vertebrate paleontology at the American Museum of Natural History in New York City. "You look at the skeleton, and there's no doubt in my mind that this is a sauropod."

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> While most temnospondyls are aquatic in early stages of life, most metoposaurids appear to have been terrestrial in their juvenile stage
reference_text: . Like other Mesozoic temnospondyls, adult metoposaurids were adapted to a semiaquatic lifestyle. Their bones are not highly developed for movement on land. The cross @-@ sectional thickness of limb bones in adult metoposaurids shows that they could not withstand the stress of terrestrial locomotion. Juvenile individuals have bones that are thick enough to withstand this stress, and could probably move about on land. To maintain a terrestrial lifestyle, a temnospondyl's limb bones would have to thicken with positive allometry, meaning that they would grow at a greater rate than the rest of the body. This is not the case in metoposaurids, meaning that as their bodies grew larger they became less adapted toward a terrestrial lifestyle.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Frogs and all other living tetrapods have a rod @-@ like bone called the stapes that aids in hearing by transferring vibrations from the ear
reference_text: drum — or homologous tympanum — to the inner ear. Temnospondyls also have a stapes, which projects into the otic cavity. The stapes likely evolved from the hyomandibula of lobe @-@ finned fishes. The positioning of the stapes and the shape of the otic region suggests that the tympani of temnospondyls and frogs are homologous, but the tympani of these amphibians are no longer considered homologous with the hearing systems of reptiles, birds, and mammals. Therefore, ear structures in temnospondyls were not ancestral to those of all other tetrapods.

In order to be able to hear, the stapes vibrates at a frequency that is in the range of 20 hertz to 20,000 hertz. This frequency is used to determine the pitch of sound, and it is the reason why frogs and toads can hear inaudible sounds such as air blowing over their heads.


Frogs are nocturnal by nature, and as a result they spend most of their time in burrows under the ground. These burrows are lined with silken material that traps air, and the frog's eardrums are protected by this insulating material. When the frog hears a sound, it has to make a decision: Do I turn my head to the sound, or do I continue to listen to the ground? If the frog is going to turn its head, it does so in a way that maximizes the amount of air that is trapped between the head and the ground. This results in the frog hearing the sound more clearly than if it had not turned its head.


So what happens when a frog hears a bird chirp? The bird is inaudible to the frog, but the frog perceives the sound as coming from the direction of the bird. In other words, the frog interprets the sound as coming from the direction of the bird, and not vice versa. This is called stereopsis

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The ability of the tympanum and stapes to effectively transmit vibrations is called impedance matching. Early tetrapods like temnospondyls
reference_text: have thick stapes with poor impedance matching, so it is now thought that they were not used for hearing. Instead, these thick stapes may have functioned to support the tissue that covers the otic notch. Early temnospondyls like Dendrerpeton could not hear airborne sound but would have been able to detect vibration in the ground. Later temnospondyls like Doleserpeton had otic regions adapted to hearing. Doleserpeton has a structure in the inner ear called the perilymphatic duct, which is also seen in frogs and is associated with hearing. Its stapes is also a better transmitter of sound. The hearing system of Doleserpeton and related temnospondyls was able to detect airborne sound and may have been ancestral to that of living amphibians.

The afferent mechanoreceptors are responsible for modulating the amplitude and time course of the oscillations that occur in the cochlea. The efferent mechanoreceptors are responsible for modulating the phase of the oscillations. This article focuses on the role of the afferent mechanoreceptors in the transmission of sound.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Osbert de Bayeux ( floruit 1121 to 1184 ) was a medieval English cleric and archdeacon in the Diocese of York
reference_text: . A relative of Thurstan, the Archbishop of York, Osbert probably owed his ecclesiastical positions to this relative. After Thurstan's death, Osbert was opposed to one of the candidates for the archbishopric, William fitzHerbert, and worked to secure fitzHerbert's deposition and replacement by Henry Murdac. After Murdac's death in 1153, Osbert tried to prevent the return of fitzHerbert, but these attempts were unsuccessful. When fitzHerbert died suddenly in 1154, Osbert was accused of murdering the newly returned archbishop. Although he was never convicted of the murder in either a secular or an ecclesiastical court, he was stripped of his clerical status and became a layman before 1158. He died after 1184, perhaps even after 1194.

Early life [ edit ]

Osbert de Bayeux was born in 1121 or 1122.[1] His father was a man of the middle class, and his mother was a member of the gentry. At the age of eight, Osmund was sent to the household of his uncle, the earl of Hereford, as a squire. He remained there until he was twelve years old, when he was sent to study at Westminster School for a year. After his attendance at the school, Osmund received a stipend of £1 a year, which he spent on books to prepare himself for clerical studies. The following year, he was ordained a deacon (i.e., a priest of the laity) and took the monastic vows of celibacy and poverty. This was the beginning of his life as a hermit.

The Sun's atmosphere is made up of hydrogen and helium, in addition to a small amount of deuterium (D 2 O). Cyclone Hengisto in the Solomon Islands is one of the strongest cyclones on record, with winds of up to 200km/h (124mph). This has led to scientists looking at the storm as a case study in how climate change is affecting weather patterns.

By analysing data from satellite images, meteorologists at the University of New South Wales in Armidale, Australia, were able to work out that there were two things that contributed to the storm's strength. One was the wind shear, which is the difference in wind speed between the surface and the top of the atmosphere. The other was the amount of convection (bubbles of air rising to the surface) in the storm.

Biography

Early life

Kemarre was born in a house with no running water, which she shared with her mother and a family of five or six children. As a child, she suffered from dyslexia and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), which made it difficult for her to read and write. At the age of six, she was sent to a boarding school for two years, where she learned to read and write with the help of tutors. Her education was interrupted by World War II, when she was conscripted into the Australian Army. In the 1950s, she worked as a domestic servant in her family's farm and on the Gold Coast, earning a living by babysitting.[1]

Career

In the '60s, Kemarre began her career as a social worker, helping people with mental health problems, drug and alcohol addictions, and learning disabilities. Head VI's origins are shrouded in mystery, but one theory is that it was an amalgam of a number of heads, or at least parts of them, that had been dismembered and put on display in the early 1950s. This is supported by the fact that there are no signs of paint splotches or blemishes on the body, which is in remarkably good condition for its age.

Other theories point to the artist's work as being based on the life of a woman called Lizzie Borden, who was murdered in 1892 by her stepfather, Horace Borden. In her deathbed confession, Lizzie admitted to strangling her father with a shoelace, and having done so, put the body in a barrel of brine and left it to decompose. The artist's head, however, has been painted in a way that suggests it is that of a more recent murder victim, rather than the 19th century one.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Bacon's output is characterised by sequences of images. He told Sylvester that his imagination was stimulated by sequences and that " images breed other images

The idea for the head series came after he returned penniless, late in 1948, from a stay in Tangier. In the previous three years he had been unable to find a voice ; the last surviving canvas from this period is his Painting ( 1946 ). Although he continued to paint, he was a ruthless self critic, given to slashing canvases with blades, and no works survive from between 1947 and the winter of 1948. Gallerist Erica Brausen offered Bacon the opportunity of a solo show for the opening of her new Hanover Gallery. He agreed, but had nothing in reserve to hang. In following years, Brausen became perhaps the most important of Bacon's early champions ; she arranged this showing — his debut solo exhibition — publicised him widely and organised viewings for international buyers.

Bacon had an interest in film and was in the vanguard of the avant-garde movement in the 1920s and 1930s. He wrote a book on cinematography, The Films of Orson Welles, and worked as a cameraman on films such as Vertigo (1958) and Citizen Kane (1941). After World War II, Bacon took up photography full-time, using Kodak Ektar film to document the Vietnam War from the point of view of soldiers. This was the first time in history that a photograph had been taken from the point of view of a war photographer.

In his work Bacon emphasised the relation between form and content, as well as the interplay between these two in relation to the artist's subject. For Bacon, there was no such thing as a work of art that was without a social or political context. "Art is the mirror of society," he wrote in one of his most famous essays, "and the more we look at society, the more we see ourselves reflected in it."

Bacon was born in 1820 to a well-to-do family in New York's Greenwich Village. His father was a lawyer and his mother worked as a governess. At the age of six, Bacon learned to paint by copying his father's canvases. In 1842, the 18-year-old moved to Paris to study at the Académie des Beaux-Arts, where he developed a love of Impressionism. After two years of study, Bacon left the academy without graduating, taking a job as a draftsman for the sculptor Édouard-Léon Polnareff. Polnareff died in 1848, leaving Bacon with a debt of $1,000. Unable to pay the debt, Bacon began to paint as a way of recouping his money. By 1849, he had completed his first series of murals, which he titled Portraits of Man and Animals. The following year, he was commissioned to paint a series of woodcuts of human figures on the side of a railroad embankment in upstate New York. This was the beginning of Bacon's career as a self-taught artist.

A self-taught photographer, Bacon began his career in the mid-1960s as a freelancer for National Geographic, which paid him $1,000 a week for eight or nine months. The START agreement limited each side to 1,550 strategic warheads, a reduction from the 2,500-warhead limit agreed to in 1987. At the same time, the United States and the Soviet Union agreed to work toward a long-term treaty to reduce the number of nuclear weapons in the world to 1,550 by the end of the decade.

Reagan, speaking from the Rose Garden, said, "I am pleased that we have reached an agreement that will lead to the elimination of nuclear weapons from the arsenals of both the United States and the Soviet Union. This is a momentous step in the history of mankind, and my hope is that it will be followed by a world in which there will be no need for nuclear weapons."

Despite these changes, the Shield continued to be one of the most popular forms of cricket in Australia, attracting crowds of over 10,000 at its peak. It was an interesting case study in the development of a new form of cricket in Australia, and one that is worth revisiting in the 21st century.

MORAKOT, Philippines (AP) — A storm that churned through the Philippines on Monday killed at least one person and caused power outages as it barreled toward the capital, Manila.

The National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council said in a statement that there were no reports of casualties so far due to the storm, which was downgraded to a tropical storm by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center.

More than 1 million people were without power in the Philippines, which is home to one of the world's busiest shipping lanes. Some of the hardest-hit areas were in Mindanao, a predominantly Muslim region where Islamic militants have waged a decades-long insurgency.

President Benigno Aquino's spokesman, Edwin Lacierda, said on Twitter that the death toll was expected to rise "significantly."

Lacierda said it was too early to say how many people were unaccounted for, but authorities were looking for "persons of interest" in the search.

Aquino declared a state of calamity and activated the military to help in the rescue and relief efforts.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> An oxaziridine is an organic molecule that features a three @-@ membered heterocycle containing oxygen, nitrogen, and carbon. In their
reference_text: largest application, oxazidines are intermediates in the industrial production of hydrazine. Oxaziridine derivatives are also used as specialized reagents in organic chemistry for a variety of oxidations, including alpha hydroxylation of enolates, epoxidation and aziridination of olefins, and other heteroatom transfer reactions. Oxaziridines also serve as precursors to amides and participate in [ 3 + 2 ] cycloadditions with various heterocumulenes to form substituted five @-@ membered heterocycles. Chiral oxaziridine derivatives effect asymmetric oxygen transfer to prochiral enolates as well as other substrates. Some oxaziridines also have the property of a high barrier to inversion of the nitrogen, allowing for the possibility of chirality at the nitrogen center.

Oxygen is the most abundant element in the universe by a factor of 1012. Nitrogen is the second most abundant element, with a mass of 0.9 x 10-34 kg/molecule. Carbon is the third most abundant element, with a mass of 0.04 x 10-34 kg/molecule. This means that there are more protons and neutrons in the universe than there are atoms of oxygen, nitrogen, and carbon. It is important to note that these numbers are relative to the size of the atom, not the mass of the atom. For example, an atom of oxygen has a mass of 1.000000000000001 kg, which is equal to the mass of one proton and one neutron. A hydrogen atom has a mass of 1.000000000000001 kg, which is equal to the mass of one proton and one neutron.

The number of nucleons in an atom is determined by the number of protons and neutrons in the atom. The number of quarks in an atom is determined by the number of up and down quarks that make up the atom. Oxygen has one proton and one neutron, nitrogen has two protons and two neutrons, and carbon has three protons and three neutrons.

Chemistry [ edit ]

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Oxaziridine derivatives were first reported in the mid @-@ 1950s by Emmons and subsequently by Krimm and Horner and Jür
reference_text: gens. Whereas oxygen and nitrogen typically act as nucleophiles due to their high electronegativity, oxaziridines allow for electrophilic transfer of both heteroatoms. This unusual reactivity is due to the presence of the highly strained three membered ring and the relatively weak N @-@ O bond. Nucleophiles tend to attack at the aziridine nitrogen when the nitrogen substituent is small ( R1 = H ), and at the oxygen atom when the nitrogen substituent has greater steric bulk. The unusual electronics of the oxaziridine system may be exploited to perform a number of oxygen and nitrogen transfer reactions including, but not limited to : α @-@ hydroxylation of enolates, epoxidation of alkenes, selective oxidation of sulfides and selenides, amination of N @-@ nucleophiles and N @-@ acylamidation.

gens. A series of pharmacological studies were carried out to elucidate the mechanism of action of oxaziridine (1-hydroxy-2-oxaziridine) and, in particular, the anticonvulsant activity against pentylenetetrazole-induced convulsions in guinea pigs.

Oxygen-deprivation (OD) or hypoxia-ischemia (HIS) is a well-known method of inducing epileptic seizures in animal models. O 2 -deprivation has been shown to decrease excitatory neurotransmission in the neocortex and cerebellum, as well as neuronal apoptosis and neurite outgrowth [1], [2]. This results in a hyperpolarization of pyramidal neurons and an increase in intracellular calcium (Ca 2+ ) [3]. The effect of O 2 -deprivation on hippocampal neurogenesis is mediated by the NMDA receptor subunit NR2B [4]. In addition, there is evidence that oxidative stress plays a role in the pathogenesis of epilepsy [5]. It has been postulated that these mechanisms underlie the anticonvulsant activity of oxaziridine [6].

reference_text: Hydroxyketones have been synthesized in many ways, including reduction of α @-@ diketones, substitution of a hydroxyl for a leaving group and direct oxidation of an enolate. Oxodiperoxymolybdenum ( pyridine ) - ( hexamethylphosphoric triamide ) ( MoOPH ) and N @-@ sulfonyloxaziridines are the most common electrophilic sources of oxygen implemented in this process. One advantage of using N @-@ sulfonyloxaziridines is that higher chiral induction is almost invariably observed relative to MoOPH and other oxidants. High yield ( 77 @-@ 91 % ) and dr ( 95 : 5 - 99 : 1 ) are reported for α @-@ hydroxylation with the Evans'chiral auxiliary with N @-@ sulfonyloxaziridine as the electrophile. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Another transformation of high synthetic utility is asymmetric epoxidation. A number of asymmetric epoxidations exist : the Sharpless epoxidation,
reference_text: the Jacobsen @-@ Katsuki epoxidation, and the Juliá @-@ Colonna Epoxidation. These methods require specific functionality in order to achieve selectivity. The Sharpless epoxidation is specific to allylic alcohols, the Jacobsen epoxidation requires cis @-@ disubstituted aryl alkenes, and the Juliá epoxidation requires α @-@ β unsaturated ketones. Chiral oxaziridines act stereospecifically on many unfunctionalized alkenes. It has even possible to effect stereospecific epoxidation catalytically in the oxaziridine chiral unit. At the far western end of the floodplain, where the mountains came down almost to the river's edge, was Dürenstein with its castle, known as Schloss Dürenstein. The castle had served as a prison for Richard I of England in 1193. In 1645 – 46, during the Thirty Years War, the Swedes had fortified the castle and then demolished it when they withdrew. It stands at 159 meters ( 522 ft ), on the highest ridge of a mountain fissured with clefts and pinnacles of granite. Because the mountain was sparsely vegetated, it was difficult to distinguish the ruins from the rocks. Narrow canyons cut through the mountain, and widen into the plain below. Between Dürenstein and Stein, on the flood plain, lay the hamlets of Oberloiben and Unterloiben. Near the hamlets, the Loiben flood plain was at its widest, extending at the most 762 meters ( 2 @,@ 500 ft ) from the base of the Loibenberg mountain to the bank of the river.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> In the broader picture, despite the important major naval engagements, the outcome of the War of the Third Coalition was determined on the Continent, predominantly in the two
reference_text: major land operations. In the Ulm campaign, the Habsburgs achieved some minor victories, such as Klenau's at Haslach @-@ Jungingen, but ultimately lost an entire army and an officer corps. The latter would not resume arms against France until formally exchanged. This condition crippled the Austrian military leadership and forced the recall of such pensioners as Schmitt out of retirement. After the capitulation at Ulm, isolated portions of the Austrian military evaded capture and joined with their Russian allies ; Michael von Kienmayer's corps slipped out of the encirclement and joined Kutuzov's force. A few other small forces refused to capitulate and seemingly melted into the Bavarian mountains and the Thurgingian forests, to reappear in Bohemia for Austerlitz. Sixteen hundred cavalry, including Archduke Ferdinand and Prince Schwarzenberg, broke out of Ulm before its capitulation. Maximilian, Count of Merveldt, led his column back through the mountains into Austria, fighting rear guard actions against pursuing French forces at the Steyer ( Steyr ) and Mariazell. These elusive units were insufficient to balance heavy losses at key battles in which the Austrians could not hold their own against the French. Between the Ulm capitulation and the Austrian and Russian defeat at Austerlitz, there were other minor achievements : a successful skirmish between the cavalry that escaped from Ulm and the French near the town of Nördlingen, the contested victory at Dürenstein, and another within days at Schöngrabern.

What is the Battle of Austerlitz?

Austerlitz was a pitched battle fought on the evening of August 21, 1805, in the Ardennes region of Germany. The Austrians, led by Archduke Eugen von Habsburg, had launched an attack on the Prussian-Belgian fortress of Eylau, hoping to gain access to the Rhine River. However, the attack was repelled by the French, who were in the process of regrouping after their defeat at Sedan.

The fact that a transformer works by inductance does not mean that it works by capacitance. There are a number of ways to look at this, but I'm going to focus on the most common of them: transformer current. This is the amount of current that flows through the transformer, divided by the resistance of the windings. For example, a 1:1 (parallel:cathode) transformer has a current of 1 ampere per square centimeter of winding. That is, one ampere flows through the winding at a time. The more turns, the higher the current. If you were to plug this into a formula, you would get something like this:


I = k*Ω, where I is the current, k is the inductance, and Ω is the permeability of the winding. So far, so good. Let's try an example. Suppose we have a winding of 0.1 ohms, and a resistance of 1 ohm. What is the current through this winding? Well, it's equal to the sum of the currents through the other two windings, which is 0.1*0.1 = 0.1A. Now, how much current is flowing through the 0.1 ohm winding? This is 0.1A/0.

On Christmas Eve, 221B Baker Street is home to a group of holidaymakers who are having a Christmas party. One of them, an elderly man, falls to his death from the roof of the house. His death is attributed to a heart attack, but there is no blood on the roof. The party goes on as usual, with no one noticing anything amiss.

At the Great Intelligence Institute, Strax the Magnificent is conducting a test on the newly-discovered Cybermen. After some convincing, he agrees to help the Doctor in his investigation of the Doctor's wife, Irene Adler, who has been missing for three years. In the TARDIS, the Doctor explains that he came to the institute to try and find her, but has run into something that makes him suspicious. Dr Simeon grabs the tin and opens it only to find the memory worm, which latches on to him. Strax informs the Doctor upon his return to the Latimer mansion that Clara only has moments left, and she passes away as the Doctor returns the TARDIS key to her. At her funeral, the Doctor reads Clara's full name on her tombstone and realises she is the woman he met in " Asylum of the Daleks " who became a Dalek, whom he refers to as " Soufflé Girl ". He gleefully announces that a person dying twice is an impossibility and, bidding farewell to his allies for now, the Doctor departs in the TARDIS to investigate and find Clara. The episode concludes in contemporary times, where a young woman resembling Clara walks through the same graveyard, pausing by Clara's tombstone.

Biography Edit

Origins Edit

The Great Intelligence was one of the most powerful Cybermen to have ever existed, and a master of time travel. When the Tenth Doctor was sent back in time to 18th century England, he came into contact with the Great Intelligence at the Battle of Bannockburn in 1314. (TV: The Five Doctors)

As well as being able to travel through time, the Great Intelligence was also capable of regenerating, although this was not its preferred method of doing so. (TV: The Five Doctors)

During the Time War, the Great Intelligence took control of Gallifrey, and planned to use it to conquer the universe. This plan was foiled by the Eleventh Doctor, who, along with Romana II, Amy and Rory, managed to escape Gallifrey's clutches. (TV: The Day of the Doctor)

Personality Edit

The Great Intelligence was cunning, devious and sadistic, with a taste for human flesh. It was an emotionless monstrosity, driven by nothing but self-preservation. (TV: The Five Doctors)

Behind the scenes Edit

According to Matt Smith, the concept of the Great Intelligence was "borrowed from Doctor Who". [1]

Synopsis Edit

The Doctor and Peri arrive in 18th century London to investigate a distress signal that may be related to the disappearance of Susan Foreman. There, they run into Jack Harkness, who has been hired by Madame Vastra to take them to Gallifrey. However, their time machine malfunctions and they end up in the middle of a battle between the Time Lords and the Daleks. During the battle, the Doctor is knocked unconscious and wakes up several years later with no memory of what happened. After regaining his memory, he sets out to find Susan's brother, Colin, and learns that Susan is the heir to the Great Seal of Gallifrey.

Executive producer James Goss told TVLine that the decision to bring back so many of the show's original cast was a no-brainer. "We're thrilled to be able to do this," he said. "It's one of those things where everyone has a lot of love for the show and wants to be a part of it, and that's the best way to make it happen."

Goss went on to say that there are no plans to recast any of the cast, which is "incredibly rare in television these days." In an interview with Digital Spy, co-creator Steven Moffat was a bit more circumspect, saying, "This is a bit of a minefield, because the cast is so well-known and people are waiting to see who's going to reappear. I can't say for sure how many people will be on the show, but it's more than half the cast of Doctor Who at the moment."

Moffat's comments come on the heels of a fan petition calling for the show to be renewed for a second season, which garnered more than 10,000 signatures in less than 24 hours. As of press time, the petition has been signed by more than 1,000 people.

A group of snowmen find themselves under attack by a man in a trench coat who turns out to be none other than the King of Arendelle, Kristoff. After an argument with his father, Olaf, the two head off to the North Mountain to try and make amends. Along the way, they run into Prince Hans, who has been searching for the fabled Iceberg of Arendelle all his life. Kristoff convinces Hans to help them in their quest, and the two set off on a journey to find the ice palace.

Synopsis Edit

The Doctor and Peri arrive on a planet where there is a time vortex that leads to the 21st century. There, they meet an archaeologist whose job is to excavate artefacts from the past. The Doctor is surprised to find that he has the key to the TARDIS, which is in the possession of the archaeologist. After some time has passed, the Doctor realises that something is wrong and goes to investigate. In the end, he comes face to face with his arch-enemy, the Cybermen. Its prime responsibility in early 1942 was maritime reconnaissance as far as New Guinea, the Solomon Islands, and New Caledonia ; the latter half of the year saw a greater focus on night bombing. Now comprising 252 officers and men, the squadron relocated to Cairns on 11 November 1942. From Cairns it continued to conduct reconnaissance, anti @-@ submarine and occasional bombing operations over the waters around New Guinea. Between December 1942 and March 1943, No. 20 Squadron's aircraft flew a total of 9 @,@ 629 hours and dropped 227 tons of bombs. The squadron's role changed in June 1943 when it commenced mine @-@ laying operations over the Netherlands East Indies and the Philippines, though it continued to make some bombing raids and supply drops.

Nos. 11 and 20 were the first of a series of air squadrons to be formed in New Guinea as part of the defence of Australia. The formation of the Australian Air Force (AAF) was one of the most significant events in the history of the Australian War Memorial. This article provides an overview of the formation of the AAF and its history.

Defence of Australia

The United Nations (UN) declared war on Germany on 9 August 1939. Australia, a self-governing colony of Great Britain, was at war with Germany for the first time since the Boer War of 1899-1902. This time, however, the war was fought on the Western Front, in the Middle East and North Africa. By the end of World War II, there were more than 2.5 million Australians serving in the armed forces, of whom more than half were overseas. A large proportion of these servicemen were from the Commonwealth of Australia, and their contribution to the war effort was significant.

In the summer of 1941, the Japanese launched an amphibious invasion of Malaya, followed by a land invasion of Hong Kong in September. These invasions created a crisis in the Pacific theatre of the war, and it was decided that Australia would play a

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> In September 1944, No. 20 Squadron became part of No. 76 Wing RAAF, along with Nos. 42 and 43 Squadrons, and moved to
reference_text: Darwin, Northern Territory. All three squadrons operated Catalinas, their primary purpose being mine @-@ laying. On the night of 30 September, a Catalina of No. 20 Squadron was shot down while attacking a ship at Pomelaa in the Dutch East Indies ; the loss was compounded by the fact that one of the coordinators of the mining campaign, Lieutenant Commander P.E. Carr of the Royal Australian Navy, was aboard the plane and was captured by the Japanese. Another of the squadron's Catalinas went down on the night of 27 / 28 January 1945, possibly in a cyclone over the Timor Sea, during the campaign to mine Surabaya. In March, a detachment of four No. 20 Squadron aircraft, along with four from No. 43 Squadron, laid mines off the coast of southern China and Formossa as part of a No. 76 Wing offensive in this area ; these operations were conducted from Leyte Gulf in the Philippines. One of No. 20 Squadron's Catalinas was lost on the night of 7 / 8 March, most likely owing to bad weather rather than enemy action. Three of the squadron's aircraft mined the entrance to Hong Kong harbour on 8 April and, on 26 May, four of its Catalinas mined Wenchow harbour in China, the furthest north that any Australian aircraft infiltrated during the war in the Pacific. Three of its aircraft flew the RAAF's last mine @-@ laying mission on 30 July.

On 1 October 1944, No. 20 Squadron was redesignated Squadron C in a re-organisation of the Flying Training School to take into account the need for pilots to be familiar with air combat tactics and the role of night vision goggles.

This was the first time in the history of the Flying Training School that there was a change in squadron name, and it was an important step in the evolution of the Flying Training School.

In the years that followed, the number of Squadron C pilots increased to the point where it became known as the 'Triple A' Squadron.

At the end of the war, Squadron C continued to fly, but on a reduced scale, as a training squadron.

By the 1950s, the flying was no longer of the highest standard, and many of the Squadron C pilots were reassigned to other units.

After the Second World War, the Flying Training School was decommissioned and became home to the Air Force Historical and Museums Service (AFHS).

A memorial commemorating the life and service of Squadron C was unveiled in the mid-1990s.

For more information, visit the AFHS website. You can also read a history of the Flying Training School by clicking here.

If you have any information for the History Detectives, please email: history@murray.nsw.

In the lead-up to the re-activations, the Australian Defence Force (ADF) held a series of briefings to inform the public about the squadron's role and role-requirements. This article provides an overview of the role of No. 20 Squadron and a brief look at the history of the squadron.

What is the role of the squadron?

Nominally a search and rescue (SAR) squadron, No. 20 Squadron has taken on a wide range of mission over the past 15 years. These include anti-submarine warfare (ASW), electronic warfare (EW), close air support (CAS), ground attack (GAT), maritime patrol (MOP), airborne early warning and control (AEW&C), transport/helicopter (H-6), special operations (SO), tactical airlift (TAL), intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance (ISR) and command and control (C2).

As well as this, the squadron has deployed to Operation Enduring Freedom (OEF) and Operation Iraqi Freedom (OIF), the most recent of which was in 2011. During this time, the squadron has flown over 2,000 sorties, with an average of more than one sortie per day.

Development Edit

The T-34 was developed by the OKB-456 design bureau in the summer of 1941. It was an all-new design, based on the KV-1 and KV-2 tanks, in line with the requirements of the Wehrmacht High Command. The design bureau aimed to create a tank that was light, manoeuvrable, and easy to maintain. This was achieved by reducing the weight of the tank to 1,500 kg (3,000 lb), which was less than the weight of the Panzer IV, PzIV, and StuG III/IV at the time. The turret was of welded-laminated steel, similar to the M4 Sherman's turret, and the hull was of cast homogeneous steel. The engine was a V-2-powered Daimler-Benz A-26-85, rated at 20 hp (15 kW) at 2,000 rpm.[1]

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The prototype of the Light Tank Mk VII ( A17 ), nicknamed'Purdah ', was first developed in 1937 by Vickers @-@
reference_text: Armstrongs as a private venture, and was intended to be sold either to the British Army or to foreign militaries. It was to be the latest in a series of light tanks produced by the company. The tank was designed to overcome the shortcomings of insufficient armament in earlier light tanks that were fitted only with machine guns. Vickers @-@ Armstrong installed on the Mk VIIs a 2 @-@ pounder 40 @-@ millimetre ( 1 @.@ 6 in ) main gun paired with a 7 @.@ 92 @-@ millimetre ( 0 @.@ 312 in ) Besa machine gun, and mounted the two guns in a two @-@ man turret. The tank possessed a maximum of 14 millimetres ( 0 @.@ 55 in ) of armour. The prototype weighed approximately 16 @,@ 800 pounds ( 7 @,@ 600 kg ) and was powered by a 165 @-@ horsepower ( 123 kW ) Meadows engine. Suspension was on eight road wheels, four per side, with no separate driver or idler wheels and it was capable of a 40 miles per hour ( 64 km / h ) top speed. The Mk VII design relied on an unusual steering method and a mechanical system incorporated into earlier Vickers models. The front wheels could be steered to allow for gentle turns by bending the tracks. For sharper turns, the system returned to the conventional method of braking one track to turn the tank ; the dual system of turning was designed to lessen mechanical strain on the MkVII and reduce its power wastage. The suspension system was also a new design that relied on struts with pockets of air for springing and cushions of oil for damping, and each of the wheels was independently sprung.

A year later, in March 1945, the U.S. Army Air Forces (USAAF) began to experiment with aircraft-launched torpedoes (ALSTAN, ALCOHOL, LIGHTNING BOLT, etc.) as a means of anti-submarine warfare. This led to the development of the P-47 Thunderbolt, which was the first aircraft to be equipped with a torpedo launcher. The P-47 had a range of 6,000 miles (10,000 km) and could reach a speed of Mach 1.5 (1,000 mph) in less than two minutes. This was a significant improvement over the time-honored V-1 and V-2 rockets, which required at least an hour to reach their targets. As a result of the Thunderbolt's performance, the United States Navy and Marine Corps decided to purchase a total of 3,000 Thunderbolts at a cost of $100 million. These aircraft were known as the "Hellcats" and flew with the 4th Fighter Group from Midway Atoll in the Pacific on Operation Downfall. After the war, the Thunderbolt was redesignated the "Thunderbolt" and went on to become one of the most successful aircraft of World War II.

A Royal Armoured Corps report issued in December 1942 stated that approximately 50 Tetrarchs were available for use. In a memorandum, dated January 1943, by Major General George F. Hopkinson, commander of the 1st Airborne Division, Hopkinson complained that he had been informed that 70 of the tanks were available, whereas only 50 actually remained, with no reserves to replace those lost in combat. This lack of sufficient replacement reserves, combined with a War Office report that some 287 airborne tanks would be required for the 1st Airborne Division and an unnamed airborne division to be formed in India, led to the Tetrarch's eventual replacement by the US M22 Locust.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The Tetrarchs remained in Britain, and would probably have been used as training vehicles before being retired from service, but on 22 June 1941 the German invasion
reference_text: of the USSR, Operation Barbarossa began, and the USSR became an ally of Britain. The Lend @-@ Lease program, begun in March 1941 by the United States of America to supply defensive materials to Britain and China, was therefore extended to the USSR. As part of the program, the British government began supplying war materials to the USSR, which in early 1942, included a shipment of 20 Tetrarchs, as well as a number of Valentine and Matilda Mk I Infantry tanks. The Soviet military utilised a greater number of light tanks than the British, and so could use the Tetrarchs. When the tanks arrived in the USSR, however, it was apparent that the design problems with the cooling system were also present in cold conditions ; additionally, the cold weather had a deleterious effect on the tank's suspension and tracks. Additional testing of the Tetrarchs was conducted by the Soviet military and the design was admired for its controllability, manoeuvrability, and speed, as well its ability to run on low @-@ quality fuel, unlike contemporary Soviet designs. The thinness of the Tetrarch's armour was found to be a problem and one which could not be solved, as the weight of extra armour plating caused an unacceptable reduction in the tank's speed. Despite these drawbacks in the Tetrarch's design, Soviet authorities believed it to be comparable to the T @-@ 70 light tank in use at the time, and decided that it was suitable to be used in combat. A number of Tetrarchs were sent to Tank Training Schools which were subsequently sent into battle, and in September 1943 two were assigned to the 132nd Separated Tank Battalion, which was attached to the 5th Guards Tank Brigade ; both tanks were destroyed in combat, one on 30 September and the other on 2 October, the latter a casualty of artillery fire. Several were also used for propaganda purposes, appearing in photographs of Soviet troops who were fighting in the Caucasus region.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The next assignment, Operation Ironclad, was the invasion of Madagascar, the third largest island in the world and then under Vichy French control. The
reference_text: Prime Minister and the Combined Chiefs of Staff decided that Madagascar should be occupied as rapidly as possible to deny the port of Antsirane to Japanese naval forces, which had recently advanced into the Indian Ocean. Operation Ironclad was under the command of Major General Robert G. Sturges and consisted of No. 5 Commando, 29th Independent Brigade Group, and the 17th and 13th brigade groups from 5th Infantry Division. The 29th Brigade formed the core of the invasion force due to its training in amphibious operations, and under its command was'B'Special Service Squadron, created by amalgamating six Valentines from'B'Squadron and six Tetrarchs from'C'Squadron into a single unit. The squadron was formed into four troops, one Headquarters troop of three Valentines and one Tetrarch, one of four Valentines, and two formed from the remaining five Tetrarchs. The invasion force assembled off the west coast of the northern tip of Madagascar on 4 May, near Antsirane and the bay of Diego Suarez. The invasion plan called for an amphibious assault landing on four beaches on the west side of the tip, which would allow the British forces to advance approximately 20 miles ( 32 km ) and approach Antsirane from the rear. Information about the landing beaches, the defences possessed by the port, and the Vichy French defending forces was limited and vague, although it was believed that the defenders had no weapons capable of penetrating the armour of a Valentine tank.

On the morning of April 1, 1942, Admiral Chester Nimitz, commander of the Pacific Fleet, issued orders to the fleet that read in part:

I am authorized to take all measures necessary to repel any attempt by the enemy to interfere with the execution of this order. It is my intention to land at Port Salut, French Guiana, on the date and at the time to be determined by the Joint Chiefs of Staff. There will be no landing in the Malagasy capital, Antananarivo, or in any other part of the island. All personnel and materiel will be landed by amphibious craft, as soon as weather permits. The landings will be carried out in accordance with the following plan: A force of 1,000-1,500 men will land on the west coast of Bougainville, about 10 miles north of the entrance to the lagoon which empties into the Bay of Biscay. By the end of the war, the 4th Hussars had fought in North Africa, the Middle East, Italy, Normandy and Flanders. During the Cold War, the RACB operated in East Germany and Czechoslovakia, as well as the former Yugoslavia. In recent years, the regiment has been based at Yeovilton in Wiltshire, where it is one of the most decorated regiments in the British Army.

Tetraarch Island is a coral atoll in the Federated States of Micronesia (Federated States of Micronesia, Free and Independent States of the Pacific Islands, Republic of Palau, Marshall Islands, Nauru, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu). It is the largest uninhabited island in the world, with a population of 1,858 (according to World Bank data).[1] The island consists of an archipelago of more than 100 islets and cays, separated by a lagoon. There are no roads, airstrips, or navigable canals on the island, and communication is by radio and shore telephones. In the 1950s, the U.S. Coast Guard established a base on the island, which was decommissioned in the mid-1980s.

The Mark VIII was also known as the Harry Hopkins, named after President Roosevelt's chief diplomatic advisor, and was given the General Staff design number A25 by the War Office. The Mark VIII was intended to improve upon the design of the Tetrarch in a number of areas. It had thicker armour than the Tetrarch, with the front hull and turret armour increased to a thickness of 38 millimetres ( 1 @.@ 5 in ) and the side armour to 17 millimetres ( 0 @.@ 67 in ), and the turret and hull given more sloped surfaces to help deflect shells fired at the tank. The dimensions of the Tetrarch were also changed ; the Mark VIII was longer by 6 inches ( 0 @.@ 15 m ), wider by 1 foot 3 inches ( 0 @.@ 38 m ) and heavier. The new tank was no longer air @-@ portable, as it was too heavy to be carried by a Hamilcar. The 12 @-@ cylinder engine of the Tetrarch was fitted to the Mark VIII, although the increased weight meant that its maximum speed decreased to 30 miles per hour ( 48 km / h ) ; its armament also remained the same as that of the Tetrarch. The War Office authorised the construction of three prototype models in April 1941. The new design was considered a success, and the Tank Board of the War Office ordered 1 @,@ 000 to be constructed in September. However, problems were encountered with further tests of the prototypes, and a report issued in December 1942 stated that production of the Mark VIII had been delayed due to developmental problems. These problems continued to persist into 1943, when the War Office decided against using the tank in active service ; approximately 100 Mark VIIIs were produced by 1945, when production ended.

The second was the Light Tank Mk IX, designed by a team led by John Browning to compete with the M4A3E8 Sherman in the United States Army Ordnance (USA) contract of 1942. Browning's design was based on the design of the Tetrarch, but differed in several ways. For example, the engine was moved to the rear of the hull, and the driver's periscope was moved forward. This would have made the tank more survivable against flak, but at the cost of weight and maneuverability. Another difference was the use of welded armor plating rather than riveted armor. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> A second variant on the Tetrarch design was the Tetrarch Duplex Drive ( " Tetrarch DD " ). The Duplex Drive system
reference_text: was invented by Nicholas Straussler, and was designed to allow a tank to'swim'through water and participate in amphibious operations. The system functioned by erecting a large waterproof canvas screen around the tank above its tracks, which was supported by thirty @-@ six inflatable tubes and steel struts ; this gave the tank sufficient buoyancy to float, and was then propelled along by a small propeller powered by the tank's engine. The screen could be collapsed by using a small explosive charge once the tank reached land. The system was fitted during June 1941, as the Tetrarch was the lightest light tank available at the time ; the converted tank was successfully tested on a number of lakes and reservoirs, allowing the Duplex Drive system to be tested on heavier tanks, such as the Valentine. The system would be used during Operation Overlord, when M4 Sherman medium tanks would land on the invasion beaches.

Gameplay

The game takes place in the Land of Ooo, where Donald and Goofy are running for their lives. There are a total of four levels, each with a different number of "lives" to complete. At the end of each level, the player is given a chance to play again, which is represented by a coin in the center of the screen. If the player chooses to play again, they start at the beginning of the level and go through the level clockwise, trying to collect as many coins as possible. In the game, coins are used to buy Power Pods, which are used to attack enemies and make them fall down to the ground. The player can also use Power Pods to jump to higher platforms, but doing so will take a lot of time, and if the player runs out of power pods, they will have to start over.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The Olmec colossal heads are at least seventeen monumental stone representations of human heads sculpted from large basalt boulders. The heads date from at least
reference_text: before 900 BC and are a distinctive feature of the Olmec civilization of ancient Mesoamerica. All portray mature men with fleshy cheeks, flat noses, and slightly crossed eyes ; their physical characteristics correspond to a type that is still common among the inhabitants of Tabasco and Veracruz. The backs of the monuments often are flat. The boulders were brought from the Sierra de los Tuxtlas mountains of Veracruz. Given that the extremely large slabs of stone used in their production were transported over large distances, requiring a great deal of human effort and resources, it is thought that the monuments represent portraits of powerful individual Olmec rulers. Each of the known examples has a distinctive headdress. The heads were variously arranged in lines or groups at major Olmec centres, but the method and logistics used to transport the stone to these sites remain unclear.

the ninth century B.C. and have been found in a variety of terracotta and porcelain vases as well as pottery sherds.

There are several theories as to their origin. Some believe that they were intended to symbolize the sun, while others point to the head and shoulders as a stylized representation of the Aztec god Quetzalcoatl. In any case, the Olmecs were masters of art and architecture, and it is no surprise that they left their mark on Mesoamerica.

One of the most famous is the "Olamacintle," a colossal head that stands on a pedestal in the center of San Lorenzo de Almagro, a city in Veracruz, Mexico. At 1,845 feet (500 meters) tall, the head is the largest and most complete Olmec sculpture to date. Although not without controversy, the origin of the head is believed to be that of Teotihuacan, the capital of the Zapotec civilization that thrived in the Yucatán Peninsula from A.D. 200 to 900.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The Olmec civilization developed in the lowlands of southeastern Mexico between 1500 and 400 BC. The Olmec heartland lies on the Gulf Coast of
reference_text: Mexico within the states of Veracruz and Tabasco, an area measuring approximately 275 kilometres ( 171 mi ) east to west and extending about 100 kilometres ( 62 mi ) inland from the coast. The Olmecs are regarded as the first civilization to develop in Mesoamerica and the Olmec heartland is one of six cradles of civilization worldwide, the others being the Norte Chico culture of South America, the Erlitou culture of China's Yellow River, the Indus Valley Civilization of south Asia, the civilization of ancient Egypt and the Sumerian civilization of ancient Iraq. Of these, only the Olmec civilization developed in a lowland tropical forest setting.

What is known about the Olmec civilization is based on what is known about Mesoamerican culture as a whole. This section of the site is an excavation area and will be used for research related to that area. Excavations are expected to continue through the summer of 2018.

Archaeological Finds

Terracotta Figurines

One of the most well-known artifacts from the Olmec civilization is the Terracotta Army, a series of finely sculpted terracotta statuettes that date to the third century BC. The Terracotta Army has been the subject of a number of books, including James Frazer's The Golden Bough (1890), which popularized the idea that the Terracotta Army was a pre-Columbian Aztec creation. However, there is no evidence that the Terracotta Army was created by the Aztecs, and it is unclear whether the figureheads were intended to represent human beings or other animals. In any case, the figures are thought to have been modeled after the gods Huitzilopochtli and

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Some of the Olmecs'rulers seem to have served religious functions. The city of San Lorenzo was succeeded as the main centre of the civilization by
reference_text: La Venta in about 900 BC, with Tres Zapotes and Laguna de los Cerros possibly sharing the role ; other urban centres were much less significant. The nature and degree of the control exercised by the centres over a widespread rural population remains unclear. Very fine Olmec art, much clearly made for an elite, survives in several forms, notably Olmec figurines, and larger sculptures such as The Wrestler. The figurines have been recovered in large numbers and are mostly in pottery ; these were presumably widely available to the population. Together with these, of particular relevance to the colossal heads are the " Olmec @-@ style masks " in stone, so called because none have yet been excavated in circumstances that allow the proper archaeological identification of an Olmec context. These evocative stone face masks present both similarities and differences to the colossal heads. Two thirds of Olmec monumental sculpture represents the human form, and the colossal heads fall within this major theme of Olmec art.

One of the most important figures in the history of the Olmecs was Tiwanaku, the "Temple of the Feathered Serpent," which was built in the 15th century B.C. to the east of Copan. Tiwanaku has been variously described as a human-headed statue, a bird of prehensile tail, a feathered serpent with serpents for legs, or a winged reptile that flew through the air. Whatever the truth, Tiwanaku symbolized the power of the sun and the fertility of the land. Inscriptions on the temple show that it was used for sacrificial feasts and as a place of worship. At the top of the temple was a platform on which were placed the heads of victims sacrificed to the sun god. These decapitated heads were placed on pedestals or plaques in the temple, and when the festival was over, the heads were ceremonially cut off and thrown into the river. The ritual of Tiwanaku was an important part of the Olmec culture, and some scholars believe that it

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The colossal heads cannot be precisely dated. However, the San Lorenzo heads were buried by 900 BC, indicating that their period of manufacture and use was earlier still
reference_text: . The heads from Tres Zapotes had been moved from their original context before they were investigated by archaeologists and the heads from La Venta were found partially exposed on the modern ground surface. The period of production of the colossal heads is therefore unknown, as is whether it spanned a century or a millennium. Estimates of the time span during which colossal heads were produced vary from 50 to 200 years. The San Lorenzo heads are believed to be the oldest, and are the most skillfully executed. All of the stone heads have been assigned to the Preclassic period of Mesoamerican chronology, generally to the Early Preclassic ( 1500 – 1000 BC ), although the two Tres Zapotes heads and the La Cobata Head are attributed to the Middle Preclassic ( 1000 – 400 BC ).

Archaeologists have found a hoard of 1,000-year-old headless and decapitated human heads in an ancient necropolis in Italy. It's the first time such a discovery has been made in the Mediterranean, and it adds to the evidence that the Romans were fascinated by death and decomposition as much as they were fascinated by art and architecture.

The discovery was made by a team of Italian archaeologists led by Massimo Polidoro, who published their findings in the journal Antiquity. In addition to the heads, they found hundreds of ceramic vases, which may have been used to decorate the coffins of the dead. [See Photos of the Burial Grotto]

Ancient burial mounds

The San Lorenzo necropolis, located in the Tuscan town of Verona, dates to the first century AD. At its peak, the city had more than a thousand tombs, each with a sarcophagus inlaid with gold and precious stones. Some of the tombs were large enough to hold up to 20 people at a time.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Olmec colossal heads vary in height from 1 @.@ 47 to 3 @.@ 4 metres ( 4 @.@ 8 to 11 @.
reference_text: @ 2 ft ) and weigh between 6 and 50 tons. All of the Olmec colossal heads depict mature men with flat noses and fleshy cheeks ; the eyes tend to be slightly crossed. The general physical characteristics of the heads are of a type that is still common among people in the Olmec region in modern times. The backs of the heads are often flat, as if the monuments were originally placed against a wall. All examples of Olmec colossal heads wear distinctive headdresses that probably represent cloth or animal hide originals. Some examples have a tied knot at the back of the head, and some are decorated with feathers. A head from La Venta is decorated with the head of a bird. There are similarities between the headdresses on some of the heads that has led to speculation that specific headdresses may represent different dynasties, or perhaps identify specific rulers. Most of the heads wear large earspools inserted into the ear lobes.

Olamcephali is the name given to the head of the Olmec civilization in Mesoamerica. It is one of the most famous heads in the world and a source of wonder for anyone who sees it. Its origin is shrouded in mystery, but scholars have come to believe that it was sculpted by Pachacuti, a priest of the Mayan god Quetzalcoatl. This may be an urban legend, but there is no doubt that the head is of great beauty and has been described as "beautiful beyond description" by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle. In his 1887 book Myths and Legends of the Aztecs, Doyle wrote: "I am in a state of amazement at the likeness of the head, which is inlaid with gold and rubies, and stands on a pedestal of the same material, so exquisitely fitted that one could look with the eye of a seer into the heart of the man who bore it." (Doyle, 1887, p. 442) A sculpture of the head was found in the ruins of Tenochtitlan, Mexico, in 1790-91 and, at that time, was thought to be a forgery. However, it was re-discovered in a museum in Tlaxcala, Mexico, in the early 1900s and proved to be genuine.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> All of the heads are realistic, unidealised and frank descriptions of the men. It is likely that they were portraits of living ( or recently deceased
reference_text: ) rulers well known to the sculptors. Each head is distinct and naturalistic, displaying individualised features. They were once thought to represent ballplayers although this theory is no longer widely held ; it is possible, however, that they represent rulers equipped for the Mesoamerican ballgame. Facial expressions depicted on the heads vary from stern through placid to smiling. The most naturalistic Olmec art is the earliest, appearing suddenly without surviving antecedents, with a tendency towards more stylised sculpture as time progressed. Some surviving examples of wooden sculpture recovered from El Manatí demonstrate that the Olmecs are likely to have created many more perishable sculptures than works sculpted from stone.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Archaeological investigation of Olmec basalt workshops suggest that the colossal heads were first roughly shaped using direct percussion to chip away both large and small flakes of
reference_text: stone. The sculpture was then refined by retouching the surface using hammerstones, which were generally rounded cobbles that could be of the same basalt as the monument itself, although this was not always the case. Abrasives were found in association with workshops at San Lorenzo, indicating their use in the finishing of fine detail. Olmec colossal heads were fashioned as in @-@ the @-@ round monuments with varying levels of relief on the same work ; they tended to feature higher relief on the face and lower relief on the earspools and headdresses. Monument 20 at San Lorenzo is an extensively damaged throne with a figure emerging from a niche. Its sides were broken away and it was dragged to another location before being abandoned. It is possible that this damage was caused by the initial stages of re @-@ carving the monument into a colossal head but that the work was never completed.

However, there is no unequivocal evidence of chipping in Olmec art, nor is there any evidence that they used tools to shape head sculpts. We report here the first case of direct percussion-carved heads, dating to the end of the 3rd millennium B.C., at a site in Oaxaca, Mexico. The heads were found in a well-preserved assemblage of prehispanic ceramics excavated from the San Bartolo de Huemul, a stratigraphic stratum that overlies the Late Pleistocene-Holocene sediments of the Cholula-Huehuetenpoort Plateau. In addition to the heads, we recovered over a dozen stone flaked figurines, as well as an array of animal and vegetal adornments associated with the heads. The presence of heads in ceramic assemblages from this time period raises the possibility that they were the work of artisans skilled in the art of chipping obsidian.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> All seventeen of the confirmed heads in the Olmec heartland were sculpted from basalt mined in the Sierra de los Tuxtlas mountains of Ver
reference_text: acruz. Most were formed from coarse grained dark grey basalt known as Cerro Cintepec basalt after a volcano in the range. Investigators have proposed that large Cerro Cintepec basalt boulders found on the southeastern slopes of the mountains are the source of the stone for the monuments. These boulders are found in an area affected by large lahars ( volcanic mudslides ) that carried substantial blocks of stone down the mountain slopes, which suggests that the Olmecs did not need to quarry the raw material for sculpting the heads. Roughly spherical boulders were carefully selected to mimic the shape of a human head. The stone for the San Lorenzo and La Venta heads was transported a considerable distance from the source. The La Cobata head was found on El Vigia hill in the Sierra de los Tuxtlas and the stone from Tres Zapotes Colossal Head 1 and Nestepe Colossal Head 1 ( also known as Tres Zapotes Monuments A and Q ) came from the same hill.

acruz, Mexico. A group of scientists led by geologist James Chatters excavated the mounds to learn more about the life and culture of the Olmecs, who lived in the Yucatán Peninsula from A.D. 900 to 1200.

What they found was nothing short of jaw-dropping. Not only were the people responsible for the world's largest pre-Columbian pyramids—more than 1,000 feet tall—they were also one of the most advanced civilizations in the Americas. For example, the Olmecs built a system of canals that allowed them to move large quantities of water from the Andes to the Gulf of Mexico, an essential resource for their agricultural and horticultural practices. This paved the way for the domestication of cotton, a crop that revolutionized the world by providing textiles for the Industrial Revolution.

In addition to all this, the Olmecs left behind an impressive record of art, architecture, ceramics, and other artifacts that date back as far as 10,000 years ago. Some of the most impressive pieces are on display at the Field Museum in Chicago, as well as at the Museo Nacional de Antropología in Mexico City. Here are some of the highlights:

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The boulders were transported over 150 kilometres ( 93 mi ) from the source of the stone. The exact method of transportation of such large masses of rock are
reference_text: unknown, especially since the Olmecs lacked beasts of burden and functional wheels, and they were likely to have used water transport whenever possible. Coastal currents of the Gulf of Mexico and in river estuaries might have made the waterborne transport of monuments weighing 20 tons or more impractical. Two badly damaged Olmec sculptures depict rectangular stone blocks bound with ropes. A largely destroyed human figure rides upon each block, with their legs hanging over the side. These sculptures may well depict Olmec rulers overseeing the transport of the stone that would be fashioned into their monuments. When transport over land was necessary, the Olmecs are likely to have used causeways, ramps and roads to facilitate moving the heads. The regional terrain offers significant obstacles such as swamps and floodplains ; avoiding these would have necessitated crossing undulating hill country. The construction of temporary causeways using the suitable and plentiful floodplain soils would have allowed a direct route across the floodplains to the San Lorenzo Plateau. Earth structures such as mounds, platforms and causeways upon the plateau demonstrate that the Olmec possessed the necessary knowledge and could commit the resources to build large @-@ scale earthworks.

Aerial view of the boulder-strewn riverbed (courtesy U.S. Geological Survey)

Geologists and paleontologists have debated for decades what caused the extinction of the woolly mammoth (Mammuthus primigenius) and mastodon (Mammuthus primigenius rex) that roamed North America more than 10,000 years ago. One theory is that climate change played a role, but there is no evidence to support this theory. Another theory is that the megafauna were hunted to extinction by humans, but this theory has been disproven by genetic studies. In this study, published in the open access journal PLOS ONE, researchers from the University of California, Merced, in collaboration with researchers from Washington State University, Pullman, in collaboration with a research team from the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, report the discovery of a previously unknown mammoth carcass in the San Joaquin Valley of California.

The remains of a mammoth were found during a survey of the Mammoth Cave National Park in Northern California. The area is known for its fossiliferous deposits, which date back as far as the Cretaceous period

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> San Lorenzo Colossal Head 1 ( also known as San Lorenzo Monument 1 ) was lying facing upwards when excavated. The erosion of a path passing on top
reference_text: of the monument uncovered its eye and led to the discovery of the Olmec site. Colossal Head 1 is 2 @.@ 84 metres ( 9 @.@ 3 ft ) high ; it measures 2 @.@ 11 metres ( 6 @.@ 9 ft ) wide and it weighs 25 @.@ 3 tons. The monument was discovered partially buried at the edge of a gully by Matthew Stirling in 1945. When discovered it was lying on its back, looking upwards. It was associated with a large number of broken ceramic vessels and figurines. The majority of these ceramic remains have been dated to between 800 and 400 BC ; some pieces have been dated to the Villa Alta phase ( Late Classic period, 800 – 1000 AD ). The headdress possesses a plain band that is tied at the back of the head. The upper portion of the headdress is decorated with a U @-@ shaped motif. This element descends across the front of the headdress, terminating on the forehead. On the front portion it is decorated with five semicircular motifs. The scalp piece does not meet the horizontal band, leaving a space between the two pieces. On each side of the face a strap descends from the headdress and passes in front of the ear. The forehead is wrinkled in a frown. The lips are slightly parted without revealing the teeth. The cheeks are pronounced and the ears are particularly well executed. The face is slightly asymmetric, which may be due to error on the part of the sculptors or may accurately reflect the physical features of the portrait's subject. The head has been moved to the Museo de Antropología de Xalapa ( " Anthropological Museum of Xalapa " ).

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> San Lorenzo Colossal Head 2 ( also known as San Lorenzo Monument 2 ) was reworked from a monumental throne. The head stands 2 @.@ 69
reference_text: metres ( 8 @.@ 8 ft ) high and measures 1 @.@ 83 metres ( 6 @.@ 0 ft ) wide by 1 @.@ 05 metres ( 3 @.@ 4 ft ) deep ; it weighs 20 tons. Colossal Head 2 was discovered in 1945 when Matthew Stirling's guide cleared away some of the vegetation and mud that covered it. The monument was found lying on its back, facing the sky, and was excavated in 1946 by Stirling and Philip Drucker. In 1962 the monument was removed from the San Lorenzo plateau in order to put it on display as part of " The Olmec tradition " exhibition at the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston in 1963. San Lorenzo Colossal Head 2 is currently in the Museo Nacional de Antropología in Mexico City. The head was associated with a number of ceramic finds ; they have been dated to the Early Preclassic and Late Classic periods. Colossal Head 2 wears a complex headdress that sports a horizontal band tied at the back of the head ; this is decorated with three bird's heads that are located above the forehead and temples. The scalp piece is formed from six strips running towards the back of the head. The front of the headdress above the horizontal band is plain. Two short straps hang down from the headdress in front of the ears. The ear jewellery is formed by large squared hoops or framed discs. The left and right ornaments are different, with radial lines on the left earflare, a feature absent on the right earflare. The head is badly damaged due to an unfinished reworking process. This process has pitmarked the entire face with at least 60 smaller hollows and 2 larger holes. The surviving features appear to depict an ageing man with the forehead creased into a frown. The lips are thick and slightly parted to reveal the teeth ; the head has a pronounced chin.

Santiago de Compostela was the capital of the Visigothic Kingdom (A.D. 711-1050) and one of the most important cities of the Iberian Peninsula. It was destroyed by Alaric the Unconquered in 1014, and a basilica was built in its place. The ruins of the basilica are on the UNESCO World Heritage List. In 2010, an earthquake of magnitude 6.5 struck the city, causing damage to the cathedral and other buildings. This resulted in the re-construction of the cathedral, which was inaugurated in 2012.

Santiago de Compostela (Saint Sebastian) was a 12th-century pilgrim who brought Christianity to Spain. According to legend, he died on the bridge of the Aranjuez, which is the most northerly bridge in the world. His body was placed on a horse and carried by the wind across the bridge for three days and three nights without anyone noticing. This legend is a part of the legend of the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem. In the Middle Ages, the city of Santiago de Compostela was an important pilgrimage site for Christians. During the Crusades, Christian pilgrims flocked to Santiago de Compostela to pay homage to Saint Sebastian. The city was inundated and all the water in the canals was turned into sludge. This is the origin of the legend that there is a treasure buried in the canal, but no one knows where it is. Some say that the treasure is in the bottom of the canal, others that it is in the waterlogged area to the north of the monument. In any case, the legend is that you can find the treasure by going down the canal in the dark, with a flashlight. This has been proven to be true by people who have done this many times.

The city was founded in 711 by the Visigoth tribes of Iberia to serve as a base for invasion of the Roman Empire. After the fall of the Roman Empire, the city fell under the control of the Moors, who were driven out in 1492. By the 16th century, the city had become a trading centre and an important pilgrimage site for Christians. During the Napoleonic Wars, the city was used as a military base by the French and, later, by the Austro-Hungarian Empire. In 1808, Napoleon Bonaparte's Grande Armée landed in the city and set up a garrison of French troops. Largest and most impressive Monument Monument in San Felipe de Asis (Córdoba, Spain) with a height of 1.5 Metres (5 ft) and width of 1.5 Metres (5 ft). The Monument consists of an obelisk (or pyramid) at the top and a series of terraces that reach to the base of the monument. There are no inscriptions on the monument, but in the shape of hieroglyphs it is known as the "Pyramid of the Sun". This monument was built by the Aztecs in the 15th century to commemorate the victory of the Inca over the Spaniards in the Battle of Campeche (1521). The Spanish conquerors took the monument as a trophy and placed it in the centre of their capital Córdoba. After the conquest of Granada in 1565, the monument was moved to Seville, where it remained until its destruction in the Civil War of 1936-1939. A restoration was carried out in the 1970s and the monument was rededicated in the Plaza de Armas in 1980. Today, the monument is open to the public every day from 9:00 am to 5:00 pm. Description

The head is made of basalt, a type of volcanic rock that is common in the Andes. There are two openings in the top of the head, which allow air to enter and a view of the surrounding area. The sides of the head are covered with hieroglyphics, but no inscriptions are visible. Some scholars believe that the head was a sacrificial offering to the gods, while others believe it was used as a religious symbol.

Geological and Paleontological Considerations

According to Dr. Henry Kautz, a professor of archaeology at the University of California, Santa Cruz, the rock that made up the head was quarried from a hill about 50 miles (80 km) to the south-southeast of the site. This is consistent with the theory that the head was part of a pyramid-like structure that was built in the area around the time of the Mayan Collapse. In any case, the presence of pyramids in the area would have been a cause for concern to the Aztecs, who were known to build pyramid-like structures on top of volcanoes.

They range in size from 20 feet (6 meters) to more than 100 feet (30 meters). The world's largest tortoise is the Galapagos giant tortoise, which can grow to a length of up to 1,500 feet (400 meters).

Tortoises are herbivores, which means they eat plants and their seeds. Their diet is rich in calcium, phosphorous, vitamin C, and amino acids. As a result, they have a low need for food, and live in areas with low population densities. This is one of the reasons why so many have been found in the Gulf of Mexico, which is known for its saltwater marshes.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Scholars and academics have offered many possible readings of American Beauty ; film critics are similarly divided, not so much about the quality of the film, as their interpretations
reference_text: of it. Described by many as about " the meaning of life " or " the hollow existence of the American suburbs ", the film has defied categorization by even the filmmakers. Mendes is indecisive, saying the script seemed to be about something different each time he read it : " a mystery story, a kaleidoscopic journey through American suburbia, a series of love stories ; [... ] it was about imprisonment, [... ] loneliness, [ and ] beauty. It was funny ; it was angry, sad. " The literary critic and author Wayne C. Booth concludes that the film resists any one interpretation : " [ American Beauty ] cannot be adequately summarized as'here is a satire on what's wrong with American life'; that plays down the celebration of beauty. It is more tempting to summarize it as'a portrait of the beauty underlying American miseries and misdeeds ', but that plays down the scenes of cruelty and horror, and Ball's disgust with our mores. It cannot be summarized with either Lester or Ricky's philosophical statements about what life is or how one should live. " He argues that the problem of interpreting the film is tied with that of finding its center — a controlling voice who " [ unites ] all of the choices ". He contends that in American Beauty's case, it is neither Mendes nor Ball. Mendes considers the voice to be Ball's, but even while the writer was " strongly influential " on set, he often had to accept deviations from his vision, particularly ones that transformed the cynical tone of his script into something more optimistic. With " innumerable voices intruding on the original author's, " Booth says, those who interpret American Beauty " have forgotten to probe for the elusive center ". According to Booth, the film's true controller is the creative energy " that hundreds of people put into its production, agreeing and disagreeing, inserting and cutting ".

of it. This article seeks to unify a number of them into a single reading, in the hope that it will be useful to those who have not seen the film, or do not wish to spend time doing so.

There are at least three ways in which one might read American Beauty. First, one might focus on the character of Norma Desmond, an African-American woman who works as a beauty parlor proprietor in Los Angeles. This is the reading that has been most popular in the United States, and for good reason: it is, in many ways, the most accurate representation of the life of a black woman in the twentieth century. Norma is a hardworking, self-reliant woman who makes a living selling her wares, but her life is marred by poverty, drug addiction, and domestic violence. As the film opens, she is on the verge of losing her business and going to prison for embezzlement, only to be pardoned by her ex-husband, played by Dustin Hoffman. After this moment of catharsis, Norma finds herself once again in the clutches of her past, this time to the accompaniment of a song by Stevie Wonder (whom she calls "Strawberry Sundae" in her letter to Woody Allen's character in Annie Hall ).

The second reading takes as its point of departure the movie's title, which comes

Mendes was inspired to make American Beauty after working on The Aviator, which was based on Upton Sinclair's The Jungle. While at Columbia TriStar, Mendes met screenwriter Aaron Sorkin, who became his mentor and mentor-in-waiting. Sorkin's The Social Network (2010) and Moneyball (2011) won Best Picture and Best Adapted Screenplay, respectively, at the Academy Awards. After that, Mendes began to take on projects that had nothing to do with Hollywood, such as David Fincher's Gone Girl (2014) and Steve McQueen's 12 Years a Slave (2013).

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Professor Roy M. Anker argues that the film's thematic center is its direction to the audience to " look closer ". The opening combines an
reference_text: unfamiliar viewpoint of the Burnhams'neighborhood with Lester's narrated admission that he will soon die, forcing audiences to consider their own mortality and the beauty around them. It also sets a series of mysteries ; Anker asks, " from what place exactly, and from what state of being, is he telling this story? If he's already dead, why bother with whatever it is he wishes to tell about his last year of being alive? There is also the question of how Lester has died — or will die. " Anker believes the preceding scene — Jane's discussion with Ricky about the possibility of his killing her father — adds further mystery. Professor Ann C. Hall disagrees ; she says by presenting an early resolution to the mystery, the film allows the audience to put it aside " to view the film and its philosophical issues ". Through this examination of Lester's life, rebirth and death, American Beauty satirizes American middle class notions of meaning, beauty and satisfaction. Even Lester's transformation only comes about because of the possibility of sex with Angela ; he therefore remains a " willing devotee of the popular media's exaltation of pubescent male sexuality as a sensible route to personal wholeness ". Carolyn is similarly driven by conventional views of happiness ; from her belief in " house beautiful " domestic bliss to her car and gardening outfit, Carolyn's domain is a " fetching American millennial vision of Pleasantville, or Eden ". The Burnhams are unaware that they are " materialists philosophically, and devout consumers ethically " who expect the " rudiments of American beauty " to give them happiness. Anker argues that " they are helpless in the face of the prettified economic and sexual stereotypes [... ] that they and their culture have designated for their salvation. "
